GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 151.001 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ALLEY. A minor right-of-way used primarily for vehicular access to the rear
or side of properties otherwise abutting on a street.
   ASSURANCE OF COMPLETION. A contract secured by a bond in an amount and with
surety satisfactory to the City Manager, guaranteeing completion of public
improvements which are shown on the subdivision improvement plan as the
responsibility of the subdivider.
   BUILDING SETBACK LINE. The line indicating the minimum horizontal distance
between the street line and buildings or any projection thereof, other than
steps and porches.
   CROSSWALKWAY. A right-of-way used primarily for pedestrian travel through or
across any portion of a block.
   CUL-DE-SAC. A short, minor street, having but one end open for motor
traffic, the other being permanently terminated by a vehicular turnaround.
   EASEMENT. A grant by a property owner of the use, for a specific purpose or
purposes, of a designated strip of land to the general public, a corporation or
other individuals.
   EXPRESSWAY. A motorway of considerable continuity designed for fast,
uninterrupted flow of vehicular traffic; having a right-of-way of varying
width; no direct access from abutting property to express traffic lanes; and no
street crossing or intersection at grade.
   EXPRESSWAY, MODIFIED. An expressway whose potential traffic volume does not
justify all of the expressway features.
   LOT. A unit area of land within a subdivision intended for transfer of
ownership or for building development.
   LOT, DOUBLE FRONTAGE. A lot with opposite ends abutting on streets.
   LOT, PANHANDLE. A lot which utilizes a narrow strip of land not a building
site having an average width of less than 50 feet and an average length of more
than 60 feet to provide access to, or legal frontage on, a public street.
   MOTORWAY. A principal arterial route designated as an expressway, modified
expressway or thoroughfare.
   PLAT OF SUBDIVISION. A map showing the division of any tract of land into
two or more parcels, and prepared for the purpose of recording. (See §
151.036 for the items of information which the plat normally includes.)
   PROTECTIVE COVENANT. A restriction on the use of private property within a
subdivision for the purpose of providing mutual protection against undesirable
aspects of development.
   PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS. Any of the following: roadway pavement, curbs, gutters,
sidewalks, crosswalks, water mains, sanitary and storm sewers and other
appurtenant construction so related to the subdivision improvement plan.
   RIGHT-OF-WAY. The entire strip of land lying between the property lines of a
street or other motorway, alley, crosswalkway or easement.
   STREET. A right-of-way designated for vehicular and pedestrian traffic,
regardless of its designation by name, such as street, avenue, land, place or
the like.
   STREET, IMPORTANT NEIGHBORHOOD. A street designated to serve as an important
traffic-way for a neighborhood, or as a feeder to a thoroughfare. The
determination of such street classification in any specific instance shall rest
with the City Planning Commission.
   STREET, MINOR. Any street other than an expressway, modified expressway,
thoroughfare or important neighborhood street.
   SUBDIVISION. As defined in R.C. § 711.001:
      (1)   The division of any parcel of land shown as a unit or as contiguous
units on the last preceding tax roll, into two or more parcels, sites or lots,
any one of which is less than five acres for the purpose, whether immediate or
future, of transfer of ownership; provided, however, that the division or
partition of land into parcels of more than five acres not involving any new
streets or easements of access, and the sale or exchange does not create
additional building sites, shall be exempted; or
      (2)   The improvement of one or more parcels of land for residential,
commercial or industrial structures or groups of structures involving the
division or allocation of land for the opening, widening or extension of any
street or streets, except private streets serving industrial structures; the
division or allocation of land as open spaces for common use by owners,
occupants or lease holders or as easements for the extension and maintenance of
public sewer, water, storm drainage or other public utilities.
(R.C. § 711.001(B))
   SUBDIVISION IMPROVEMENT PLAN. A drawing showing a proposed subdivision of
land together with the public improvements which are to be installed therein.
Such drawing is not recordable. (See §§
151.080 through
151.092 and
151.105 through
151.111 for the items of information which the plan normally includes.)
   THOROUGHFARE. A street of considerable continuity designed as a major
traffic-way. This category does not include an expressway or modified
expressway.
   ZONING. Regulation by districts of the height, area, and use of buildings,
use of land, and density of population.
(Prior Code, § 151.001) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES
§ 151.015 APPLICABILITY OF PROCEDURES.
   Any person desiring to subdivide any lot, tract or parcel of land or to
change or rearrange any such lot, tract or parcel shall comply with the
procedures established herein.
(Prior Code, § 151.015) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.016 PRELIMINARY INFORMATION.
   The subdivider shall notify the City Manager in writing of his or her
intention to subdivide a property. Such notification shall include mention or
illustration of any aspect or feature which will affect the design or layout of
the subdivision. For clarity, preliminary information may utilize a map to
illustrate various features or aspects of the property.
(Prior Code, § 151.016) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.017 PRELIMINARY CONFERENCE.
   (A)   Within one week after submission of the preliminary information, or
another mutually agreeable time, the City Manager (or designee) and the
subdivider shall meet to review the elements of the proposed subdivision. To
this conference the subdivider should bring the following data:
      (1)   Intended land use. Designation of land proposed for residential,
industrial, commercial or other type land use;
      (2)   Location map with reference to the community. A map which shall
show the overall relationship of the proposed subdivision to main traffic
arteries, existing minor streets, existing water mains and sanitary and storm
sewer facilities with an indication of the size of each, of all shopping
centers, schools, parks, playgrounds, railroads, airports, hospitals, churches
or other community facilities or features which will either serve or influence
the proposed subdivision; and
      (3)   Site analysis sheet. A topographic survey or topographic map of the
property to be subdivided at a scale which will give all pertinent information
without becoming a size which is cumbersome. Such survey or map shall contain
thereon the proposed subdivision name, a scale, north arrow, date, the
perimeter, boundary of the proposed subdivision, all existing public utilities,
natural features such as rock outcrops, tree masses and watercourses which are
either on, adjacent to or near the property to be subdivided.
   (B)   At this meeting, the following topics will be discussed:
      (1)   The City Manager will make certain that the subdivider is
acquainted with the procedures set up by this chapter; and
      (2)   The elements of design for the proposed subdivision:
         (a)   Setback requirements;
         (b)   Alignments and width of streets;
         (c)   Rights-of-way required;
         (d)   Needs of major street plan;
         (e)   Minimum lot requirements;
         (f)   Minimum frontage requirements;
         (g)   Hazards which require special attention;
         (h)   Streets which must be extended;
         (i)   Street access to adjacent undeveloped property;
         (j)   Handling of waterways on the site; and
         (k)   Other appropriate topics.
(Prior Code, § 151.017) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.018 SUBMISSION AND PROCESSING OF PRELIMINARY PLAT.
   (A)   Submission of preliminary plat. After the conference described in §
151.017, the subdivider shall file eight copies of the preliminary plat,
prepared in accordance with §
151.035, with the City Manager at least two weeks prior to the meeting of the
Planning Commission at which action is desired. A letter to the Commission
requesting the plat be processed and containing any other pertinent information
or requests the subdivider wishes to convey shall accompany the submission of
the preliminary plat.
   (B)   Processing of the preliminary plat.
      (1)   The preliminary plat and the letter of submission shall be checked
by the City Manager as to its conformance and the requirements of the
preliminary plat as stated in §
151.035. If the preliminary plat does not meet the requirements of §
151.035, the elements of design discussed at the preliminary conference, the
requirements of the major street plan, the requirements of the zoning code or
any other part of these regulations, the City Manager shall return the
preliminary plat to the subdivider with a letter of rejection stating the
reasons for its rejection. However, at his or her discretion, the City Manager
may forward the preliminary plat not meeting all requirements to the Commission
with a statement of the irregularities for its conditional approval or
rejection. If the plat is found satisfactory, the City Manager will submit it
to the Commission with a written recommendation for the Commission’s review and
decision.
      (2)   The Commission may approve the plat, approve it with conditions or
disapprove it. Upon approval of the preliminary plat by the Commission, the
Commission’s Secretary will indicate upon each copy that it has been approved.
One copy shall be returned to the subdivider, one copy shall be returned to the
City Manager and two copies shall be retained by the Commission. If
disapproved, the Commission’s Secretary shall return, to the subdivider, one
copy of the preliminary plat marked “Disapproved by the Madeira Planning
Commission”, along with a letter stating the reason or reasons for its
disapproval. One copy shall be given to the City Manager and two copies filed
by the Commission’s Secretary.
(Prior Code, § 151.018) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.019 SUBMISSION AND APPROVAL OF SUBDIVISION IMPROVEMENT PLANS.
   (A)   Submission of the subdivision improvement plan. On receipt of the
approved preliminary plat, the subdivider may instruct a registered
professional engineer to prepare plans for streets and sidewalks, sanitary
facilities and stormwater drainage, in accordance with the specifications
established or referred to herein. The subdivider, or his or her engineer,
shall submit to the City Manager three copies of the improvement plans prepared
according to accepted practices, which should not exceed 30 by 42 inches and be
drawn at a scale of 50 feet or less to the inch horizontally and ten feet or
less to the inch vertically. The plans should be accompanied by stormwater run-
off sheets and calculations, and if necessary, percolation tests, all certified
by a registered professional engineer.
   (B)   Checking and approval of the subdivision improvement plans. The
improvement plans shall be checked by the City Manager to ensure that they meet
the specifications established in §§
151.050 through
151.066,
151.080 through
151.092 and
151.105 through
151.111 for streets, sanitary facilities and all associated appurtenances. If
found satisfactory, the City Manager shall approve the plans and transmit one
copy to the subdivider. If unsatisfactory, the City Manager shall approve with
modification, or disapprove the plans and shall notify the subdivider thereof,
including a statement of modifications or reasons for disapproval.
(Prior Code, § 151.019) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.020 ISSUANCE OF PERMITS.
   Upon approval of the improvement plans, the subdivider may then obtain from
the City Manager the necessary permits to proceed with the complete or partial
development of the subdivision, as set forth in §§
151.080 through
151.092 and
151.105 through
151.111 of these regulations.
(Prior Code, § 151.020) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.021 SUBMISSION, PROCESSING AND APPROVAL OF SUBDIVISION PLAT.
   (A)   Submission of subdivision plat. After the completion of all
improvements to the satisfaction of the City Manager, or after successful
completion of the posting of an accepted performance bond, the final plat will
be accepted and processed by the City Manager. The subdivider and three clear
and legible copies of the subdivision plat, as described in §
151.036 of these regulations. The subdivision plat shall be accompanied by a
certificate of title showing the ownership of all lands to be dedicated for
public use and that the title thereof is free and unencumbered.
   (B)   Processing the subdivision plat. The City Manager will check the
subdivision plat as to description, certification, computations, lot areas and
numbers, monuments, conformity with the approved preliminary plat and other
pertinent aspects. If found satisfactory, the City Manager will transmit to the
Commission the subdivision plat, and two copies, along with the attorney’s
report of title and a certification that:
      (1)   The technical details of the subdivision plat itself have been
checked and found to be satisfactory; and
      (2)   Either all improvements have been completed in a satisfactory
manner, or that a satisfactory performance bond agreement has been furnished.
   (C)   Approval of subdivision plat.
      (1)   After the subdivision plat, together with such certificates, have
been received by the Commission, and provided that the subdivision plat is
found to conform to the preliminary plat as approved, the Commission will
approve the subdivision plat and the Chairperson shall so certify on the
original copy. The Commission shall take action on the subdivision plat within
60 days after its submission to the City Manager. The original copy of the
approved subdivision plat, with signatures of approval, shall be returned to
the subdivider for recording with the County Clerk.
      (2)   If the approved subdivision plat is not recorded within six months
after the approval date, such approval shall be null and void. The Commission’s
Secretary shall transmit two copies of the subdivision plat, with the
certificate of title, to the City Council, for necessary action on the proposed
dedications. One copy shall be retained for the files of the Commission. In the
event the subdivision plat is disapproved, the original drawing and two copies
shall be returned to the subdivider accompanied by a letter from the
Commission’s Secretary stating the action taken and the reasons for disapproval
of the subdivision plat.
(Prior Code, § 151.021) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.022 ESTABLISHING A MINOR SUBDIVISION.
   (A)   A proposed division of a parcel of land along an existing public
street, not involving the opening, widening or extension of any street or road,
and involving no more than five lots after the original tract has been
completely subdivided, may be submitted to a representative designated by the
Planning Commission for the purpose of reviewing such proposed division, and if
found not contrary to applicable platting, subdividing or zoning regulations,
he or she shall within seven working days after submission of such proposed
division approve the same, and, on presentation of a conveyance of said parcel,
stamp the same “Approved by the Madeira Planning Commission, No Plat Required”.
Such representative may require the submission of a sketch and such other
information as is pertinent to his or her determination hereunder.
   (B)   Plats of subdivision will not be required for subdivisions as defined
in R.C. § 711.001 for subdivisions not involving the opening or extension of
any street or easement of access and in which past subdivision and development
has so far proceeded that the preparation and recording of a plat would serve
no public or planning purpose. The representative is authorized to approve
conveyances without a plat in such cases as are expected herein. In case of
doubt, such representative may refer the question to the Planning Commission.
If such representative refuses approval for a subdivision without a plat, the
applicant may appeal to the Board of Zoning Appeals.
(Prior Code, § 151.022) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970; Ord. 17-10, passed 9-25-
2017)
Statutory reference:
   Approval by planning authority without plat, see R.C. § 711.131
FORM AND CONTENT OF PLATS
§ 151.035 PRELIMINARY PLAT.
   (A)   Form of preliminary plat. The subdivider shall file with the City
Manager eight copies of the preliminary plat for review. The minimum dimensions
of this plat shall be 18 inches by 26 inches. No plat shall be greater than 30
inches in width nor 42 inches in length. The plat shall be drawn at a scale of
100 feet or less to the inch. The preliminary plat shall be accompanied by a
letter of submission which requests that the plat be processed and which points
out any feature or subject concerning the subdivision which the subdivider
considers pertinent.
   (B)   Content of preliminary plat. The preliminary plat shall clearly show:
      (1)   Proposed name of the subdivision, which shall not duplicate or too
closely approximate, phonetically or in spelling, the name of any other
subdivision in the county;
      (2)   Locations by section, township, range, county, state;
      (3)   Names and addresses of owner or developer, of the technician who
made the plan, and of engineer responsible for engineering details;
      (4)   Sufficient information to accurately locate the plat (Note:
references to existing thoroughfares, plats and the like may be used if they do
not exist within reasonable distances of the proposed subdivision; a vicinity
plat on a small scale shall accompany the preliminary plat);
      (5)   The boundary lines of the tract accurately indicated by a heavy,
solid line and the acreage comprised therein;
      (6)   The lines and names of all existing or platted streets and other
public ways adjacent to or in connection with the tract and other important
features within 200 feet of the boundary lines, such as railroad lines,
watercourses, exceptional topography and the like;
      (7)   The lot lines and subdivision names of adjacent subdivisions and
the property lines and owners of record of all adjacent parcels that are
unsubdivided;
      (8)   Location and dimension of all existing easements and rights-of-way
within the tract or adjacent thereto;
      (9)   All existing sewers, water mains, culverts and other underground
structures within the tract or adjacent thereto;
      (10)   Sources of water supply;
      (11)   Provision for sewerage and sewage disposal;
      (12)   Approximate contour lines having the following interval:
         (a)   Five-foot contour interval for ground slopes between 5% and 15%;
and
         (b)   Ten-foot contour interval for ground slopes exceeding 15%.
      (13)   The layout and names of proposed streets, alleys, easements and
lots, and dimensions signifying widths of streets, alleys, easements, and lots
and depth of lots (Note: proposed street names shall not duplicate or too
closely approximate, phonetically or in spelling, existing street names in the
county);
      (14)   Lot and block numbers proposed;
      (15)   Statement of the lot area of the smallest lot in the subdivision;
      (16)   Building setback lines shown graphically with dimensions along all
streets;
      (17)   A statement declaring that all requirements for front, rear and
side yards will be met;
      (18)   Parcels of land intended to be dedicated or temporarily reserved
for public use, or to be reserved by deed covenant for use of all property
owners in the subdivision, or parcels of land or lots to be used for any
purpose other than private residential shall be so designated;
      (19)   Approximate location of areas subject to inundation or stormwater
overflow, and all areas covered by water and all watercourses which are to be
preserved and used in the development of the subdivision;
      (20)   An outline of the proposed deed restrictions;
      (21)   The approximate profile of each street with tentative grades
indicated;
      (22)   The cross-section of proposed streets showing width of roadways
and location of sidewalks;
      (23)   Zoning district boundary line as established under the zoning code
(Chapter 150); and
      (24)   North point, scale and date.
(Prior Code, § 151.035) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.036 SUBDIVISION PLAT.
   (A)   Form of subdivision plat. Each subdivision plat shall be submitted in
the form of an original drawing, in waterproof ink, together with three clear
and legible copies.
   (B)   Specifications for and contents of subdivision plat. Subdivision plats
shall be drawn at a scale of 50 feet to one inch, with at least a two-inch
margin on the left side, and not larger than 30 inches in width and 42 inches
in length, and shall clearly show:
      (1)   Boundary lines, with accurate lengths, angles and bearings. These
boundaries shall be determined by an accurate survey in the field, which shall
be balanced and closed;
      (2)   The exact location and width of all existing and recorded streets
intersecting or adjoining the boundaries of the subdivision tract;
      (3)   The exact location and width of all adjoining lots or property
lines;
      (4)   All dimensions shall be accurate to hundredths of a foot, and
angles and bearings accurate to the exact number of minutes for the following:
         (a)   Streets and alley lanes, their names, bearings, angles of
intersection and widths;
         (b)   The lengths of all arcs, radii, points of curvature, tangent
bearings;
         (c)   All easements and rights-of-way for public services (the
limitations of easements rights shall be stated on the plat); and
         (d)   All lot lines, with dimensions, bearings and angles (if other
than right angles to street and alley lines).
      (5)   Building setback, lines and distances from rights-of-way;
      (6)   All lots, consecutively numbered or lettered with no omissions or
duplications;
      (7)   Accurate description of location, material, and size of all
monuments (R.C. § 711.03 requires at least four permanent monuments for each
subdivision of ten lots or less);
      (8)   The accurate outline of all land that is offered for dedication for
public use, with the purpose indicated thereon, and of all property proposed to
be reserved by private covenant for the common use of the property owners in
the subdivision;
      (9)   Private restrictions, if any, and boundaries for each type of
restriction;
      (10)   Protective covenants. If recorded separately, reference to book
and page of recording shall be made on the subdivision plat;
      (11)   The sidelines of all easements shall be shown by fine dash lines;
      (12)   Name of the subdivision;
      (13)   The names and addresses of the subdivider and of the engineer or
surveyor;
      (14)   A certification by a state-registered engineer or surveyor to the
effect that the plat accurately represents a survey made by him or her, that
all monuments shown thereon actually exist or will be installed, and that their
position is correctly shown;
      (15)   A certification that the applicant is the owner and a statement by
such owner dedicating streets, rights-of-way, and any other sites for public
use, and creating any easements and specifying the purpose of such easements;
and
      (16)   North point, scale and date.
   (C)   Plats required; exemptions. No subdivision defined in R.C. § 711.001,
shall be made of land within the jurisdiction of the Planning Commission
without the preparation and recording of a plat of subdivision in accordance
with this chapter, except as exempted from such platting by this chapter or by
R.C. § 711.131.
(Prior Code, § 151.036) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
RULES FOR LAYOUT OF SUBDIVISIONS
§ 151.050 INTERPRETATION BY PLANNING COMMISSION.
   All contested interpretations of these rules and regulations shall be
decided by the Planning Commission.
(Prior Code, § 151.050) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.051 CONFORMITY TO MAJOR STREET PLAN.
   The arrangement, character, extent, width, grade and location of all streets
shall conform to such major street plan, adopted by the Planning Commission, as
may be in force at the time such streets are planned and constructed, and shall
be considered in its relation to existing and planned streets, to topographical
conditions, to public convenience and safety, and in its appropriate relation
to the proposed uses of the land to be served by such streets and the
prospective development and access to adjacent land. Where not shown on the
major street plan, the arrangement and other design standards of streets shall
conform to the provisions found herein.
(Prior Code, § 151.051) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.052 STREET EXTENSIONS.
   (A)   Existing streets. The arrangement of streets in new subdivisions shall
make provisions for the proper continuation of existing streets in adjoining
areas.
   (B)   Adjacent property. Where areas adjoining a proposed subdivision are
not subdivided and are appropriate for a subdivision, arrangements of streets
in new subdivisions shall make provisions of the practical development of the
adjacent property, permit a feasible extension of streets, and be in general
conformity with a plan for the most advantageous development of the entire
neighborhood.
(Prior Code, § 151.052) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.053 DEDICATED RIGHTS-OF-WAY.
   (A)   Minimum right-of-way widths.
      (1)   Expressways, modified expressways and thoroughfares: 100 feet;
      (2)   Important neighborhood streets and state roads: 60 feet;
      (3)   Minor streets: 60 feet for pavements 44 and 36 feet in width, 50
feet for pavements less than 36 feet in width. Cul-de-sacs shall terminate in a
circular area with a minimum diameter of 80 feet. T-turnarounds are permitted
on residential streets if the abutting lots have depth of no more than 110 feet
from the normal street right-of-way line. T-turnarounds are recommended for
industrial subdivisions. They shall measure 100 feet by 60 feet;
      (4)   Alleys: 20 feet; and
      (5)   Crosswalkways: a minimum of four feet on each side of the
designated centerline, or such width as may be required for necessary
maintenance of utility involved.
   (B)   Existing streets. Subdivisions platted along existing streets shall
dedicate additional rights-of-way if necessary to meet the minimum street width
requirements set forth in the foregoing section. Such dedication shall be in
accordance with the following:
      (1)   At least the minimum right-of-way width shall be dedicated where
the subdivision is on both sides of the existing street; and
      (2)   When the subdivision is located on only one side of an existing
street; one-half of the required right-of-way width, measured from the
centerline of the existing roadway, shall be dedicated. However, in no case
shall the owner or owners of such property be forced to dedicate from their
land more than one-half the total right-of-way width. Dedication of less than
minimum width of rights-of-way for streets proposed along the boundaries of
land to be subdivided shall be prohibited.
(Prior Code, § 151.053) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.054 INTERSECTIONS.
   (A)   Right-of-way. Streets and alleys at their intersections shall be
provided with at least 20-foot radius turns at property lines in all
subdivisions other than industrial subdivisions, in which case the radii shall
be such as to provide 40-foot radii at curb lines. These minimum radii shall be
increased when the angle of intersection is less than 75 degrees. In business
districts a cutoff may be substituted for the circular arc. Where two alleys
intersect, a ten-foot cutoff shall be provided.
   (B)   Slope. Whenever a street intersects another street, no part of the
centerline of one street within 50 feet of the near curb line of the other
street shall have a slope above such intersection in excess of 8% or below such
intersection in excess of 6% and the maximum grade of either street within an
intersection shall be 4%.
   (C)   Angle of intersection. The centerlines of streets shall intersect as
nearly at right angles as possible, but in no case shall they intersect at less
than 75 degrees or more than 105 degrees.
   (D)   Jogs. Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than 200 feet shall
be avoided.
(Prior Code, § 151.054) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.055 HORIZONTAL AND VERTICAL CURVES.
   Sight distance on all streets shall be established in accordance with the
following.
   (A)   Curvature. The minimum radius of curvature for arterial streets shall
be 300 feet on the centerline, and for local service streets 100 feet on the
centerline.
   (B)   Reverse curves. A tangent of at least 100 feet in length shall be
provided between reverse curves.
   (C)   Grade changes. All changes of grade shall be connected by vertical
curves of minimum length equal to 15 times the algebraic difference in the rate
of grade for main and secondary thoroughfares and one-half this minimum length
for minor or local service streets.
(Prior Code, § 151.055) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.056 STREET GRADES AND ELEVATIONS.
   The grade of no street shall be less than 0.8% or exceed 12% unless
necessitated by exceptional topography, and the grade of main or secondary
thoroughfares shall not exceed 7%.
(Prior Code, § 151.056) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.057 DEAD-END STREETS.
   Dead-end streets designed to be so permanently, shall be provided with a
turnaround having an outside diameter of at least 80 feet at the property line.
(Prior Code, § 151.057) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.058 PRIVATE STREETS AND RESERVE STRIPS.
   (A)   If at all feasible, new private streets, alleys or ways shall not be
created or extended and existing ones shall be brought into the ultimate plan
for the area.
   (B)   Reserve strips controlling the access to streets or other public
rights-of-way shall not be approved unless such strips are deemed necessary for
the protection of the public welfare or substantial property rights as
determined by the Planning Commission.
   (C)   Where deemed necessary by the Planning Commission, a temporary
turnaround or a temporary connection to another street shall be provided by the
subdivider. Such streets shall be built in accordance with specifications on
file in the City Manager’s office.
(Prior Code, § 151.058) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.059 STREET NAMES.
   (A)   Duplication. The name of a new street shall not duplicate existing or
platted street names in the county or approximate such names in spelling or
sound of pronunciation or by the use of alternate suffixes such as “Lane”,
“Way”, “Drive”, “Court”, “Avenue” or “Street”.
   (B)   Continuation of streets. New streets in continuation or when in
alignment with an existing or platted street shall bear the name as such
street.
   (C)   Approval of street name. All street names shall be approved by the
Planning Commission before approval of the subdivision plat.
(Prior Code, § 151.059) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.060 PROVISION OF ALLEYS.
   (A)   Residential alleys. Alleys shall be avoided in residential districts.
   (B)   Commercial and industrial alleys. In commercial and industrial areas,
adequate alleys or off-street loading and unloading space, where needed for
loading and unloading or access purposes, shall be provided.
(Prior Code, § 151.060) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.061 FLOOD HAZARD AREAS.
   (A)   Prohibition of development in flood susceptible areas. Land subject to
flooding and land deemed to be topographically unsuitable for residential
development shall not be platted for residential use or for any other use which
may increase the danger of health, life, property or aggravate erosion or flood
hazards. Such land within the subdivision shall be set aside on the plat for
such uses as will not be endangered by periodic or occasional inundation or
will not result in conditions contrary to the public welfare. To ensure that
lots will be located where they will provide flood-free home sites, the
Commission may require the subdivider to provide elevation and flood profiles
sufficient to demonstrate the sites will be free from the danger of flooding.
   (B)   Stream easement. If a stream flows through or adjacent to the proposed
subdivision, the plat shall provide for a floodway easement. For the smaller
streams, the plat shall also provide for channel improvement to carry all
reasonable floods within banks. The lower floor elevations of houses shall be
high enough to be well above the extraordinary flood. The floodway easement
shall be wide enough to provide for future enlargement of the stream channel as
adjacent areas become more highly developed and runoff rates are increased.
   (C)   Streets. Approval will not be given for subdivision streets which
would be subject to inundation or flooding. In order that no portion of the
subdivision would become isolated by floods all streets must have flood-free
elevations.
(Prior Code, § 151.061) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
Cross-reference:
   Construction in flood hazard areas, see
Ch. 156
§ 151.062 BLOCKS.
   (A)   Arrangement. The arrangement of blocks shall be such as to provide for
convenient access, circulation, control and safety of street traffic.
   (B)   Length. Blocks shall not exceed 1,200 feet or be less than 400 feet in
length except as the Planning Commission considers necessary to secure
efficient use of land or desired features of street layout.
   (C)   Width. The width blocks shall ordinarily be sufficient to allow for
two tiers of lots with rear easements as required.
(Prior Code, § 151.062) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.063 LOT REGULATIONS.
   (A)   Size. Lot arrangement and design shall be such that lots will provide
satisfactory sites for buildings and shall be properly related to topography.
All platted lots shall conform to or exceed the requirements of the zoning
district in which they are located and the use for which they are intended.
   (B)   Frontage and width.
      (1)   Generally. Lots fronting on a street having a centerline radius of
less than 600 feet and lots fronting on the rounded end of a cul-de-sac shall
conform to the minimum width at the building line, and the minimum frontage at
street right-of-way as required by the zoning code (Chapter 150);
      (2)   Double frontage. Lots with double frontage shall be avoided except
where essential to provide separation of residential development with traffic
arteries or otherwise required by topography or orientation; and
      (3)   Corner lots. Corner lots shall be made wider than the required
minimum width for interior lots to permit conformance to the setback line on
the side street. In no case shall a corner lot be so narrow that minimum zoning
requirements cannot be met.
   (C)   Lot depth.
      (1)   Conformance to zoning. Each lot shall be of such a depth that front
yard and rear yard requirements of the zoning code plus a reasonable building
site shall be provided.
      (2)   Maximum depth. The maximum depth of a lot shall not be greater than
three times the width of the lot except in unusual cases, and lots which
contain over five acres of area. Lots over five acres of area shall not be less
than 250 feet in width at any location.
      (3)   Extra depth and width in certain cases. Additional depth shall be
required where a residential lot in a subdivision backs up to a railroad right-
of-way, a high pressure gasoline or gas line, arterial road, and industrial
area or other existing land use which has a detrimental effect on the
residential use of the property and where no street is provided at the rear of
such lot. Where a residential lot has its side line adjacent to any of the
above, appropriate additional width shall be required.
   (D)   Usable lots.
      (1)   Building lots. All subdivisions shall result in the creation of
lots which are developable and capable of being built upon. No subdivision
shall create lots which are impractical for improvement due to steepness of
terrain, dangerous soil conditions, location of watercourses or other natural
physical conditions.
      (2)   Uninhabitable lots. Proposed lots which do not provide a site
capable of being built upon or are not free from flooding shall be deemed to be
uninhabitable and shall not be platted for residential occupancy nor for such
other uses as may increase danger to health, life or property, or aggravate
flood hazards, but such land within the subdivision shall be set aside for such
uses which are not endangered by periodic or occasional inundation or which
will not produce unsatisfactory living conditions. Acceptable fill material may
be used in inundated areas to render lots habitable if such fill does not
inhibit the flow of the waters and thereby unduly increase flood heights.
      (3)   Strips or parcels. No remnants of property shall be left which do
not conform to lot requirements or which are not required for a private or
public utility purpose, or which are not accepted by the city for an
appropriate use.
      (4)   Lot side lines. The side lines of lots shall normally be straight
and so far as practical, should preferably be at right angles to straight
street lines and radial to curved street lines of that street toward which the
lot faces.
   (E)   Large lots. When land is subdivided into parcels which are larger than
normal lots, these shall be of such shape and dimensions as to render possible
the re-subdivision of any such parcels into normal lots and streets in
accordance with these regulations.
(Prior Code, § 151.063) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
Cross-reference:
   Zoning code lot requirements, see §
150.013
§ 151.064 PEDESTRIAN WAYS.
   (A)   Location. Pedestrian ways, at least ten feet in width including a
paved walkway at least four feet in width, may be required as follows:
      (1)   Near the center and entirely across the block for blocks which are
over 900 feet in length;
      (2)   To correct dead-end streets; or
      (3)   To provide access to parks, schools, shopping centers or similar
facilities.
   (B)   Grade. The grade of no pedestrian way shall exceed 15% unless steps of
an acceptable design are constructed.
(Prior Code, § 151.064) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.065 EASEMENTS.
   (A)   Utility easements. Public utility easements at least ten feet in total
width may be required along the rear and sides of lots where needed for the
accommodation of a public utility, drainage or sanitary structure, or any
combination of the above. Where deemed necessary by the Planning Commission,
additional easement width shall be provided.
   (B)   Watercourses. The subdivider shall dedicate rights-of-way or provide
easements for storm drainage purpose which conform substantially with the lines
of any natural watercourses, channels, streams or creeks which traverse the
subdivision or for any new channel which is established to substitute for a
natural watercourse, channel, stream or creek. Such rights-of-way or easements
shall be of a width which will provide for the maintenance needs of the channel
and incidental structures.
   (C)   Slope easements. Where a cut or fill road slope is outside the normal
right-of-way of the street, a slope easement shall be provided of sufficient
width to permit maintenance of the slopes by the city.
(Prior Code, § 151.065) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.066 PUBLIC SITES.
   Due consideration must be given to the allocation of suitable property for
schools, parks and playgrounds, to be dedicated, or to be reserved for the
common use of all property owners within the subdivision by covenant in the
deeds. Especially appropriate for such preservation are areas with unusual
natural feature or beauty and areas of historical significance. The Planning
Commission may require that at least 5% of the net area of every plat,
exclusive of streets, should be set aside as a play area or park. Where the
tract contains less than 40 acres, such reservation for open space should be
combined, wherever possible, with similar reservations of adjoining tracts.
(Prior Code, § 151.066) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
PUBLIC IMPROVEMENT REGULATIONS
§ 151.080 GENERAL REQUIREMENTS; BOND.
   (A)   For subdivisions platted within the jurisdiction of the Planning
Commission and in which improvements as mentioned hereafter or elsewhere in
these regulations are involved, such improvements shall have been:
      (1)   Constructed or installed; and
      (2)   Accepted for maintenance by the appropriate agency or organization
prior to the consideration of the subdivision plat by the Commission.
   (B)   However, in lieu of such completion and acceptance, the Commission may
accept the existence of a bond, certified by the City Law Director as valid and
enforceable by the city, to secure to the city the actual construction and
installation of such improvements or utilities at a time and according to the
approved improvement plans.
(Prior Code, § 151.080) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.081 IMPROVEMENTS TO BE MADE IN OFFICIAL STREETS ONLY.
   No board, public officer or authority shall accept, lay out, improve or
authorize utilities to be laid in any street within the territory for which the
Planning Commission has adopted a major street plan unless the street has
received the legal status of a public street prior to the adoption of the major
street plan; or unless the street corresponds with a street shown on the major
street plan; or unless the street is shown on a subdivision plat or a street
plat which has been approved by the Planning Commission.
(Prior Code, § 151.081) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.082 STREET SPECIFICATIONS.
   Streets shall be graded, surfaced and improved in accordance with plans,
profiles and cross-sections prepared by the subdivider and approved by the City
Manager. The plans shall detail construction in accordance with specifications
on file in the City Manager’s office. Under no circumstances shall any street
be constructed with a traveling surface less than 27 feet wide. The Planning
Commission may require construction with a traveling surface greater than 27
feet wide for streets other than minor streets. All subsurface drainage
facilities and utilities shall be installed prior to placing the street
surface.
(Prior Code, § 151.082) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.083 ALLEY SPECIFICATIONS.
   All alleys shall be graded, surfaced and improved in accordance with plans,
profiles and cross-sections prepared by the subdivider and approved by the City
Manager. The work shall be performed in the manner prescribed in the applicable
specifications of the city.
(Prior Code, § 151.083) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.084 STORM DRAINAGE.
   (A)   An adequate drainage system including necessary stabilized open
ditches, pipes, culverts, intersectional drains, drop inlets, bridges and the
like shall be provided for proper drainage of all surface water. Cross drains
shall be provided to accommodate all natural water flow and they shall be of
sufficient length to permit full width roadways and the required slopes. The
size openings to be provided shall be determined by accepted engineering
practice, but in no case shall the pipe be less than 12 inches in diameter. The
design of storm drainage facilities shall be in accordance with storm drainage
design criteria prepared by the City Engineer and approved by the City Manager.
Where any natural watercourse is to be disturbed or blocked, adequate provision
shall be made to handle the water. Cross drains shall be built on a straight
line and grade and shall be laid on a firm base, but not on rock.
   (B)   Pipes shall be laid with their spigot ends pointing in the direction
of the flow and with their ends fitted and matched to provide tight joints and
a smooth uniform invert. They shall be placed at a sufficient depth below the
roadbed to avoid dangerous pressure of impact, and in no case shall the top of
the pipe be less than two feet below the roadbed. The City Manager will refer
storm drainage plans to the City Engineer for approval of design.
(Prior Code, § 151.084) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.085 SIDEWALKS.
   Concrete sidewalks shall be provided on both sides of all streets, in
accordance with applicable specifications of the city.
(Prior Code, § 151.085) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.086 STREET NAME SIGNS.
   Street name signs of a type which conforms to applicable specifications of
the city shall be installed as follows:
   (A)   One street sign at the intersection of two minor streets; and
   (B)   Two street signs on diagonally opposite corners where a minor street
intersects with a major thoroughfare or collector street, or where a collector
street intersects a major thoroughfare, or where two collector streets or two
major thoroughfares intersect.
(Prior Code, § 151.086) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.087 SANITARY FACILITIES.
   (A)   The subdivision shall be provided with a sanitary sewerage network
which shall be connected to a sanitary sewer system of a governmental
subdivision or its agency, and comply with the requirements of the appropriate
public authority.
   (B)   Upon written determination by the Metropolitan Sewer District that
sanitary sewers are not accessible, aerobic treatment systems will be permitted
if approval has been obtained from all appropriate governmental agencies,
including the Board of Health and the Metropolitan Sewer District, and the
State Environmental Protection Agency. The aerobic treatment system will comply
with all applicable sections of the State Department of Health’s Home Sewage
Disposal Rules as existent on the date of adoption of this division (O.A.C. §§
3701-29-01 to 3701-29-21, effective January 1, 2015). In addition, the
following requirements apply:
      (1)   Each lot must have its own aerobic system;
      (2)   Class I aerobic systems shall be used;
      (3)   Pickup lines are the responsibility of each homeowner; two or more
pickup lines shall be considered a sewer system;
      (4)   Discharge to be piped to the evident watercourse;
      (5)   Chlorinators suitable for Class I systems must be installed,
maintained and secured by a lock box, all to be maintained at the property
owner’s expense;
      (6)   The system must be serviced at intervals in accordance with
manufacturer’s recommendation, or every six months. The homeowner shall
maintain adequate records and make those records available to the City Manager
upon request;
      (7)   The homeowner must permit such inspections as are requested by the
County Board of Health or the city; and
      (8)   In any zoning district, the minimum lot size shall be 20,000 square
feet and 80 foot minimum width (excluding handle of panhandle lot).
   (C)   Whenever the Metropolitan Sewer District determines that a sanitary
sewer is available to a property, the aerobic sewage system shall be abandoned
and the property sewer directly connected to the sanitary sewer within 24
months.
   (D)   All lots shall have installed by the builder and approved by the
Metropolitan Sewer District, piping for future sanitary sewers, which shall be
connected at the earliest time unless this requirement is waived or modified by
the Planning Commission.
(Prior Code, § 151.087) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970; Ord. 88-27, passed 6-4-
1988)
§ 151.088 WATER DISTRIBUTION SYSTEM.
   In the city, the water distribution system shall be designed and installed
to meet the approval of the City Manager and the director of the affected water
district.
(Prior Code, § 151.088) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.089 FIRE HYDRANTS.
   Standard fire hydrants shall be installed by the subdivider as a part of the
water distribution system in accordance with the specifications established by
the City Manager. Installation of fire hydrants shall be such that each lot is
within 250 feet of the fire hydrant when measured along a public right-of-way.
(Prior Code, § 151.089) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.090 UTILITY CONNECTIONS.
   Each lot shall be provided with a source of standard electrical currents. A
network of rights-of-way and easements shall be provided for utility services.
Such easements will be located at the rear of lots whenever feasible, and shall
be in conformance with the needs of the utility company. All utility services
shall be underground as provided for in Ordinance 1017, which is made a part of
these regulations.
(Prior Code, § 151.090) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.091 GRADING, EXCAVATIONS AND FILLING.
   (A)   All grading, excavating and filling shall be in accordance with this
chapter.
   (B)   Grading shall consist of all clearing and grubbing, excavation,
embankment, ditching, rolling, beading and shaping required to bring the entire
width of the right-of-way to the required alignment, grade and cross-section
shown on the plans.
      (1)   Preparation of subgrade. The entire right-of-way area shall first
be cleared of all tree stumps, roots, brush and other objectionable materials
and of all trees not intended for preservation. The subgrade shall be properly
shaped, rolled and uniformly compacted in accordance with the latest edition of
Construction and Material Specifications issued by the State of Ohio Department
of Highways. The City Manager may require tests by a testing laboratory to
verify conformance with compaction requirements.
      (2)   Cuts. In cuts, all tree stumps, boulders, organic material, soft
clay, spongy materials and other objectionable materials shall be removed to a
depth of at least two feet below the natural ground surface. Fill material will
comply with this chapter.
      (3)   Fills. In fills, all tree stumps, boulders, organic material, soft
clay, spongy materials and other objectionable materials shall be removed to a
depth of at least two feet below the natural ground surface. Fill material will
comply with this chapter.
      (4)   Cut slope. No proposed cut slope shall be steeper than one and one-
half horizontal to one vertical, except as hereinafter provided.
      (5)   Fill slope. No fill slope, existing or proposed, shall be steeper
than two vertical to one horizontal, except as hereinafter provided.
      (6)   Retaining walls.
         (a)   Retaining walls of a permanent material and of a design
satisfactory to the City Manager may be utilized in areas of excessive slopes;
and
         (b)   Retaining walls may be required whenever topographic conditions
warrant or where necessary to retain fill or cut slopes within the rights-of-
way or slope easement.
      (7)   Top soil. If grading results in the stripping of top soil, the top
soil shall not be removed from the site or used as spoil and shall be uniformly
spread over the lots as grading is finished.
      (8)   Trees. As many trees as can be reasonably utilized in the final
development plan shall be retained and the grading adjusted to the existing
grade of the trees.
      (9)   Drainage system requirements. The design of storm drainage
facilities shall be in accordance with storm drainage design criteria prepared
by the City Engineer and approved by the City Manager. (See §
151.084.)
      (10)   Road drainage system. 
         (a)   The road storm system shall serve as the primary drainage
system.
         (b)   It shall be designed to carry roadway, adjacent land and house
stormwater drainage.
         (c)   No stormwater shall be permitted to be run into the sanitary
sewer system.
            1.   Curb drainage inlets shall be provided at intervals along
roadways provided with curb and gutter drainage facilities, and a catch basin
shall be installed with each inlet.
            2.   Inlet spacing shall be adequate to limit the spread of water
to two feet into the roadway. Storm drain inlets will be spaced so that
crosswalks will not be flooded during the design storm intensity of four inches
per hour.
      (11)   Proximity of open watercourse to houses. No open watercourse or
ditch shall be constructed within 100 feet of the rear of a house, as measured
from the house to the edge of the ditch easement.
      (12)   Drainage courses along side lot lines. Any major storm drainage
courses carried along side lot lines shall be enclosed with approved pipe.
(Prior Code, § 151.091) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.092 STREET TREES.
   Street trees shall be provided as required by the Planning Commission as
follows.
   (A)   Species. The trees shall be species which are resistant to damage and
disease and which do not cause interference with underground utilities or
street lighting.
   (B)   Location. 
      (1)   Street trees shall be spaced so that there will be approximately
ten feet between branch tips when the trees are fully grown.
      (2)   No trees shall be planted within 40 feet of the intersection of two
street right-of-way lines.
      (3)   Approaches to buildings should be considered when locating trees.
   (C)   Tree size. Trees shall be at least one and one-half inches in diameter
one foot above the ground. Lowest branches shall be not less than seven feet
and no more than ten feet above the ground.
(Prior Code, § 151.092) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
CONSTRUCTION OF PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS
§ 151.105 PRECONSTRUCTION MEETING AND WORK SCHEDULE.
   Prior to the commencement of any project involving the Planning Commission
or the City Manager, a preconstruction meeting will be held to discuss the
project in regard to procedure, materials, inspections and the like.
(Prior Code, § 151.105) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.106 INSPECTIONS.
   (A)   Responsible official. The City Manager shall be responsible for the
inspection of all improvements.
   (B)   Authority and duties of inspectors.
      (1)   Inspectors employed by the city shall be authorized to inspect all
work done and all materials furnished. Such inspection may extend to all or any
part of the work and to the preparation, fabrication or manufacture of the
materials to be used. The inspector shall not be authorized to revoke, alter or
waive any requirements of the specifications or plans. He or she shall be
authorized to call the attention of the contractor to any failure of the work
or materials to conform to the specifications and contract. He or she shall
have the authority to reject materials which do not meet specification
requirements or suspend the portion of the work involved until any question at
issue can be referred to and decided by the City Manager.
      (2)   Periodic inspection during the installation of improvements shall
be made by the inspector to ensure conformity with the approved plans and
specifications as contained in the subdivider’s construction agreement.
   (C)   Final inspection. Upon completion of all the improvements, the
subdivider shall request, in writing, a final inspection by the City Manager.
The City Manager shall make a final inspection of streets, sanitary and storm
sewers.
(Prior Code, § 151.106) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.107 DUTIES OF THE SUBDIVIDER OR CONTRACTOR.
   The subdivider or contractor shall have available on the project, at all
times, two copies of all required plans and specifications. He or she shall
cooperate with the inspector and with other contractors in every way possible.
The subdivider and/or contractor shall, at all times, have a competent
superintendent acting as his or her agent on the project. The superintendent
shall be capable of reading and thoroughly understanding the plans and
specifications and he or she shall receive instructions from the inspector. The
superintendent shall have full authority to execute the orders or directions of
the inspector and to promptly supply such materials, tools, plant equipment and
labor as may be required. The inspector’s orders should be executed without
delay. A superintendent shall be furnished irrespective of the amount of work
sublet.
(Prior Code, § 151.107) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.108 GRADE STAKES.
   Pavement and pipe grade stakes shall be set at 25-foot intervals on
horizontal and vertical curves and for all grades less than l%. Tangent
pavement grades and pipe grades over 1% may be set at a maximum interval of 50
feet. The inspector may ask for additional grade stakes if it is deemed
necessary.
(Prior Code, § 151.108) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.109 REPAIR OF DAMAGE; FINAL CLEANUP.
   (A)   Any damage done to the improvements by construction traffic, local
traffic or by any other means shall be repaired or the damaged materials
replaced before the next item of construction is begun.
   (B)   Upon completion of the work and before acceptance, the subdivider or
contractor shall clean up all ground occupied or affected by him or her in
connection with the work. The entire area shall be kept in a neat and
presentable condition during the entire duration of the project, and left in a
neat and presentable condition satisfactory to the inspector.
(Prior Code, § 151.109) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.110 MAINTENANCE OF IMPROVEMENTS.
   The subdivider shall be responsible for the maintenance of the improvements
installed and shall be responsible for providing the services necessary to
guarantee access to all occupied lots, including plowing snow, until final
acceptance by City Council. The subdivider shall be given adequate and
appropriate notice by the City Manager of the need for the maintenance or
service within an appropriate time. The City Manager may perform said service
and bill the subdivider for said service. Payment shall be guaranteed by the
performance bond. The subdivider shall maintain all improvements for such
periods specified in the maintenance guarantees.
(Prior Code, § 151.110) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
§ 151.111 CONSTRUCTION AGREEMENTS; MAINTENANCE GUARANTEES.
   All bonds and insurance required under this section shall be secured from
companies authorized to do business in the State of Ohio and shall be deposited
and remain at all times with the City Clerk.
   (A)   Construction agreement. To assure construction and installation of
improvements required by these regulations, the subdivider shall execute a
construction agreement with the City Manager in form and substance approved by
the city’s legal counsel. This agreement shall provide that all such
improvements shall be constructed and installed at the subdivider’s expense in
compliance with the standards and specifications for each of the various types
of improvements; such improvements shall be available to and for the benefit of
the land within the subdivision and surrounding land which is in the same
service or drainage area. Any further provisions that the city’s legal counsel
may deem necessary in the public interest may be added. The construction
agreement shall further provide that when a performance guarantee has been
provided and if the improvements are not completed within the specified time,
the city, upon proper notice, may complete the improvements and recover full
costs and expenses thereof from the subdivider, and may appropriate such
portion of bonds posted for the faithful performance of said works.
   (B)   Commencement of improvements. No construction of any improvements or
clearing, grubbing and grading shall commence prior to the approval of the
construction agreement by the City Manager.
   (C)   Maintenance guarantee. The maintenance bond shall be of such amount as
determined by the City Manager and shall be arranged for a period of one year
for streets constructed with concrete pavement (includes a one-year period for
all other improvements also).
(Prior Code, § 151.111) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
VARIANCES
§ 151.125 VARIANCES TO BE BASED ON HARDSHIP.
   Where the Board of Zoning Appeals finds that unique practical difficulties
and extraordinary hardships from unusual conditions may result from strict
compliance with any of these regulations, it may vary the regulations so that
substantial justice may be done and the public interest secured; provided that
such variation will not have the effect of nullifying the intent and purpose of
these regulations.
(Prior Code, § 151.125) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970; Ord. 17-10, passed 9-25-
2017)
§ 151.126 CONDITIONS UPON GRANT OF VARIANCE.
   In granting variances and modifications, the Board of Zoning Appeals shall
require and may impose such additional requirements and conditions regarding
the location, character and other features of the proposed uses as it may deem
necessary to secure substantially the objectives of the standards or
requirements of these subdivision regulations, to carry out the intent and
purpose of the subdivision regulations, and to otherwise safeguard the public
health, safety and general welfare.
(Prior Code, § 151.126) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970; Ord. 17-10, passed 9-25-
2017)
§ 151.127 PUBLIC HEARING; NOTICE OF DECISION.
   (A)   Prior to making a decision on any application, the Board of Zoning
Appeals shall notify by mail of the time and place of a public hearing, the
property owner or petitioner and all abutting property owners who, in the
opinion of the Board of Zoning Appeals, may be affected by such variance.
   (B)   Following the public hearing and the completion of any additional
studies or acquisitions of additional data necessitated by hearing, the Board
of Zoning Appeals shall make a decision within 30 days and notify the property
owner or petitioner of such decision.
(Prior Code, § 151.127) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970; Ord. 17-10, passed 9-25-
2017)
CHARGES AND FEES
§ 151.140 PRELIMINARY PLAT FEES.
   (A)   Fees for preliminary plats. There shall be required by the Planning
Commission a fee for each subdivision plat submitted for approval. Such fee
will not exceed the following:
      (1)   For plats of three to six lots, tracts or parcels or less, a
minimum fee of $750;
      (2)   For plats of seven to 12 lots, tracts or parcels, a minimum fee of
$1,500;
      (3)   For plats of 13 to 18 lots, tracts or parcels, a minimum fee of
$2,250; and
      (4)   For plats in excess of 18 lots, tracts or parcels, a fee of $3,000,
plus $100 for each additional lot, tract, or parcel in excess of 18.
   (B)   Architectural Review Office fee. The Architectural Review Office fee
shall be an additional 25% of the preliminary plat fee.
(Prior Code, § 151.140) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970; Ord. 88-11, passed 3-7-
1988)
§ 151.141 FINAL PLAN CHECKING AND FIELD INSPECTION FEES.
   (A)   At the time final subdivision plans, development plans, plans,
profiles and specifications are submitted for review, the City Manager shall
prepare an estimate of the cost of reviewing and inspection of all improvement
plans. The subdivider shall thereupon deposit an additional amount of money, as
well as any Architectural Review Office fee, equal to the estimated cost. All
work done by the City Manager in connection with checking, computing and
correcting such plans for improvements shall be charged against the deposit.
   (B)   If, during the progress of the work, the cost thereof appears to
exceed the amount so deposited, the City Manager shall notify the subdivider of
this fact and shall do no further work in connection with such review until the
subdivider has deposited such additional sum of money determined necessary by
the City Manager to cover the cost of the work. The subdivider shall also pay
to the City Manager a fee to defray the total cost of field inspection of the
improvements.
   (C)   The inspection fee shall be determined by the City Manager. The
subdivider is held responsible for all inspection fees which will be payable
monthly. The bond posted by the subdivider guarantees the payment of all
inspection fees and no bonds will be released until all inspection fees have
been paid in full.
   (D)   The City Manager shall be under no duty to proceed to view any plans
or have any plans reviewed until such deposit is placed with the city.
(Prior Code, § 151.141) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970; Ord. 88-11, passed 3-7-
1988)
§ 151.142 PAYMENT OF FEES.
   The filing fee, plan checking and field inspection fees shall be paid in
legal tender or by check or money order made payable to the city and deposited
with the City Manager.
(Prior Code, § 151.142) (Ord. 1030, passed 10-19-1970)
