§ 152.01 BUILDING DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED.
   There is established a Building Department for the city, with authority to
approve plans and specifications and enforce the Ohio Building Code for
commercial construction and the Residential Code of Ohio for residential
construction within the corporate limits of the city.
(Prior Code, § 152.01) (Ord. 726, passed 2-6-1961; Ord. 1087, passed 3-20-1972)
§ 152.02 BUILDING CODES ADOPTED BY REFERENCE.
   A certain document, a copy of which is on file in the office of the Building
Department of the city being marked and designated as the Ohio Building Code
for commercial construction and the Residential Code of Ohio for residential
construction as adopted by the Ohio Board of Building Standards pursuant to
R.C. § 3781.10, be and is hereby adopted as the Ohio Building Code for
commercial construction and the Residential Code of Ohio for residential
construction for regulating and governing the construction, alteration,
movement, enlargement, replacement, repair, equipment, location, removal and
demolition of detached one- and two-family dwellings and multiple single-family
dwellings (townhouses) not more than three stories in height with separate
means of egress as herein provided; providing for the issuance of permits and
collection of fees therefor; and each and all of the regulations, provisions,
penalties, conditions and terms of said Ohio Building Code for commercial
construction and the Residential Code of Ohio for residential construction on
file in the office of the city are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part
hereof, as if fully set out in this section, with the additions, insertions,
deletions and changes, if any.
(Prior Code, § 152.02) (Ord. 91-22, passed 3-4-1991; Ord. 05-19, passed 8-22-
2005; Ord. 06-26, passed 9-25-2006)
§ 152.03 ADMINISTRATION OF BUILDING CODE.
   The Building Department of the city shall be administered by the City
Manager, acting as Building Inspector. All plans and specifications for the
erection within this city of public buildings or parts and appurtenances
thereof that may be used as places of resort, assembly, education,
entertainment, lodging, dwelling, trade, manufacture, repair, storage, traffic
or occupancy, or use for any other purpose, by the public excepting only
single-family, two-family and three-family dwelling houses, shall be approved,
and the construction of the buildings shall be inspected by an architect or
professional engineer that is registered in the state and has at least five
years’ experience in building construction or design, if the City Manager is
not himself or herself so qualified for such building plan approval and
inspection, engaged for such purposes as a member of the staff of the Building
Department, either on a full-time or part-time basis.
(Prior Code, § 152.03) (Ord. 726, passed 2-6-1961; Ord. 1087, passed 3-20-1972)
§ 152.04 BUILDING PERMIT REQUIRED AND BUILDING PERMIT FEES.
   (A)   Commercial and public buildings.
      (1)   New buildings, alterations, additions and repairs. A flat fee of
$100 for plan review plus
$5 per $1,000 based on estimated costs will be charged. This cost shall include
site development (landscaping, paving, parking, parking lots and the like),
heating, cooling, ventilating systems and wrecking. All commercial plans shall
be subject to the ARO fee as outlined in §
150.030 and a 3% State Board of Building Standards review fee levied by the
state.
      (2)   Re-roofing and fences. A flat fee of $100 shall be charged.
      (3)   Gutters and downspouts/storm drains. A flat fee of $100 shall be
charged.
      (4)   Ductless space heaters, floor furnaces, fireplaces, infrared
heaters or other low heat producing appliances.
         (a)   500,000 BTU and under: $100 first unit, $25 each additional unit
in same building; and
         (b)   Over 500,000 BTU, fee to be figured in accordance with division
(B)(2) of this section.
      (5)   Power or process steam boilers. A flat fee of $100 per unit shall
be charged, plus an additional $25 for each additional unit.
      (6)   Signs and billboards. Signs and billboards will require a separate
permit under this division (A)(6).
         (a)   Walls signs. One dollar per square foot, minimum fee of $100.
         (b)   Projecting signs. One dollar per square foot, minimum fee of
$100.
         (c)   Roof signs, including billboards and advertising roof signs. One
dollar per square foot, with a minimum fee of $100.
         (d)   Temporary signs. A flat fee of $25 shall be charged.
         (e)   Ground signs, including billboards and other advertising signs
fastened to the ground. One dollar per square foot, minimum fee of $100.
      (7)   Fire protection sprinkler system.
         (a)   Fire protection (sprinkler and fire suppression systems) will
require a separate permit.
         (b)   Permit fee for wet or dry type system shall be $15 per 1,000
aggregate square feet, gravity or pressure tanks, or fire pumps included as an
integral part of the system.
      (8)   Fire suppression systems. Dry chemical for hoods, ducts, surface
protection:
         (a)   Where the cost is not more than $500, the fee is $50;
         (b)   Where the cost is more than $500, but less than $1,000, the fee
is $75; and
         (c)   Where the cost is $1,000 or more, the fee is $75 plus $40 for
each $1,000 or fraction thereof over $1,000.
      (9)   Smoke, fire and security systems. The fee shall be based on
furnished and installed contract price cost basis using fee schedule contained
in this division (A).
      (10)   Drainage reviews. The fee shall be based on the per hour rate
established per contract with the City Engineer.
      (11)   Temporary structures. Temporary structures with a construction
cost of less than $5,000. A flat fee of $50 plus $5 for each 100 square feet of
area or fraction thereof, based on outside dimensions.
   (B)   Residential, single- and two-family dwellings. (Three-family or more
dwellings will be governed by division (A) of this section.)
      (1)   New dwelling. Flat fee of $950 for plan review plus $100 for each
1,000 square feet of area or fraction thereof, based on outside dimensions of
the structure of each floor level to include basement, cellar and sub-cellar
floors. This fee when stated or shown on the original submission includes fees
for driveway curb cuts, patios, street openings, parking lots, heating systems
and other items normally requiring a permit if done separately.
      (2)   Alterations, additions and repairs, including detached garages.
         (a)   General. Based on the estimated cost of work the fee schedule
shall be as follows:
            1.   Where the cost is not more than $500, the fee is $40;
            2.   Where the cost is more than $500, but not more than $1,000,
the fee is $65; and
            3.   Where the cost is more than $1,000, the fee is $65 plus $15
for each $1,000 or fraction thereof, over and above the first $1,000.
         (b)   Detached sheds and other accessory or temporary structures with
a construction cost of less than $5,000. A flat fee of $30 plus $5 for each 100
square feet of area or fraction thereof, based on outside dimensions shall be
charged.
         (c)   Reroofing and fences. A flat fee of $100 shall be charged.
         (d)   Gutters and downspouts/storm drains. A flat fee of $100 shall be
charged.
         (e)   Swimming pools. Family type swimming pools manufactured for
above-ground and partially in-ground up to 20 feet in diameter, or 20 feet
square/rectangular shall be charged $50. Above 20 feet and in-ground
construction pools shall be included in division (B)(2)(a) of this section.
   (C)   Moving of buildings. A permit shall be obtained for each operation of
moving a building from a location in the city to another location. Where the
new location is upon another lot in the city, a permit shall be obtained for
constructing a new basement or foundation and such information shall be
provided as would be provided for any new building, such as proposed elevation
of floors in relation to ground, proposed grading of yard, location of sewers,
and the like. The fee for the moving work shall be based on the estimated cost
of the moving. It shall be determined in accordance with division (B)(2) of
this section.
   (D)   Wrecking. A flat fee of $50 per building or structure, up to two
stories including basement and roof, plus a flat fee of $15 for each additional
story and sub-basement shall be charged.
   (E)   New or replaced furnaces/air conditioning.
      (1)   Furnaces. A flat fee of $100 shall be charged for the first unit
and an additional $25 for each additional unit.
      (2)   Air conditioning. A flat fee of $50 shall be charged for the first
unit and an additional $25 for each additional unit.
   (F)   Ductless space heaters, floor furnaces, fireplaces, infrared heaters
or other low heat producing appliances.
      (1)   500,000 BTU and under; $100 first unit, $25 each additional unit in
same building; and
      (2)   Over 500,000 BTU, fee to be figured in accordance with division (B)
(2) of this section.
(Prior Code, § 152.04) (Ord. 87-18, passed 5-4-1987; Ord. 88-46, passed 11-7-
1988; Ord. 88-62, passed 7-10-1989; Ord. 89-89, passed 11-29-1989; Ord. 92-81,
passed 12-7-1992; Ord. 93-20, passed 3-15-1993; Ord. 97-68, passed 1-12-1998;
Ord. 02-46, passed 1-13-2003; Ord. 04-33, passed 12-13-2004; Ord. 17-11, passed
12-11-2017; Ord. 24-04, passed 7-22-2024)
§ 152.05 CONFORMANCE TO BUILDING AND ZONING CODES; REVOCATION.
   No dwelling house or public building shall hereafter be erected,
constructed, repaired, altered or removed, nor shall the equipment of any such
building or of the premises thereof be hereafter erected, constructed,
installed, repaired, altered or removed, except in conformity with the City
Building Code governing the same, and pursuant to approval of the plans and
specifications in connection therewith, and issuance of a building permit
therefor, by the Building Department. It shall likewise be unlawful to occupy
or use any such building or equipment that has been erected, constructed,
altered or otherwise dealt with in violation of such code. Plans and
specifications submitted for such approval shall clearly indicate the
intentions of the applicant relative to all items, elements and aspects of
construction, occupancy, and use regulated by the code and the city zoning
code; and at the time of such submission for approval, one complete set shall
be furnished to the Building Department for its permanent retention. All
dimensions shown on such plans relative to location and size of lots shall be
based on actual survey; and the lot to be built upon, and the location of the
structure to be built thereon, shall be staked out before construction is
started. Building permits shall expire when no construction is started
thereunder within six months from date of issuance, and may be revoked when
construction thereunder is discontinued for one year, or when there is
violation thereof under any of the provisions of such Building or zoning code
or any of the terms of such permits, or when the continuance of any work
thereunder becomes dangerous to life or property.
(Prior Code, § 152.05) (Ord. 726, passed 2-6-1961; Ord. 854, passed 10-18-1965;
Ord. 1087, passed 3-20-1972) Penalty, see §
152.99
§ 152.06 UNSAFE, DANGEROUS, OR UNSANITARY BUILDINGS.
   Whenever it shall appear that an unsafe, dangerous or unsanitary condition
exists in connection with any building subject to the provisions of this
chapter, or that any condition exists constituting a violation of any provision
of this chapter or of any law relating to the same subject matter, the Building
Inspector shall forthwith give notice of such condition or violation to the
owner or agent in charge of such building, and shall order the same to be made
safe, secure or sanitary, and to be placed in substantial compliance with the
provisions of this chapter, or to be taken down and removed.
(Prior Code, § 152.06) (Ord. 726, passed 2-6-1961; Ord. 1087, passed 3-20-1972)
Penalty, see §
152.99
§ 152.07 ERECTION AND REMOVAL OF STRUCTURES WITHIN CERTAIN AREAS.
   (A)   The erection of any structure or of any additions to any structure is
prohibited in the following described area in the city unless the outer walls
and frame of the structures or additions are constructed of brick and mortar,
stone, concrete or other fireproof material.
   (B)   This section shall not prohibit the use of ornamental wooden trim on
structures so long as it meets with the approval of the Building Inspector.
   (C)   The areas to be covered by the restrictions in this section known as
the fire limits of the city shall be all areas that are presently located or
hereafter located in Business A, Business B and Business O under the existing
zoning code or any amendments thereto.
   (D)   No structure or addition to a structure shall be moved from one lot to
another within this area or moved from an area not covered by this section into
the fire limits ordinance section unless the outer walls and frames and
additions meet the requirements of division (A) above.
   (E)   This section shall not apply to any temporary building not over one
story in height erected for the temporary use of any builder or contractor
engaged in construction operations within this area, the erection and use of
which is necessary to the carrying out of the operations. No building shall be
erected or moved into the area without a permit therefor from the City Manager.
The building shall be removed by the builder or contractor promptly upon
completion of the operations.
   (F)   Any structure or any addition to any structure erected contrary to, or
not removed in accordance with, the provisions of this section shall, after 30
days’ written notice to the owners or agent of the owners of the structure or
addition, be removed by and pursuant to the order of the Manager, and the
expense of removal shall be charged to the owners.
   (G)   The provisions of this section shall govern. They shall prevail over
any prior ordinances and parts of ordinances in conflict with these provisions.
(Prior Code, § 152.07) (Ord. 989, passed 11-12-1970; Ord. 1087, passed 3-20-
1972; Ord. 1155, passed 3-18-1974) Penalty, see §
152.99
§ 152.08 NOTICE TO REPAIR OR DEMOLISH BUILDING; ACTION BY CITY.
   (A)   If any such building shall in the opinion of the Building Inspector
represent an immediate hazard to life or property, his or her notice shall
order remedial action to be taken forthwith, and shall require the owner or
agent served to advise him or her in writing immediately as to the intention of
such owner or agent with reference thereto. If, within 24 hours after service
of a notice, the owner or agent fails so to advise the Building Inspector, or,
in lieu thereof, fails to comply fully with the order, or if at any time the
owner or agent refuses to comply with the order, or advises the Building
Inspector of his or her intention to comply and then fails to proceed promptly
with such compliance, or commences such compliance and fails diligently to
carry it to completion, the Building Inspector shall be authorized to enter
upon the subject premises, without further delay, with force sufficient to make
such building or any part thereof, secure or to demolish or remove it as he or
she may consider necessary for the public safety and welfare. The owner of the
subject premises, or any other persons responsible therefor, shall be liable to
the city for the entire cost thereby incurred.
   (B)   In any event, and in every case the Building Inspector shall cause a
written or printed notice to be placed on the premises as a warning to the
public.
(Prior Code, § 152.08) (Ord. 726, passed 2-6-1961; Ord. 1087, passed 3-20-1972)
Penalty, §
152.99
§ 152.09 ORDER TO VACATE BUILDINGS.
   The Building Inspector shall be authorized to order the vacation of
buildings when occupied; or when any work, operation or construction is being
performed therein or thereon is in violation of any of the provisions of this
chapter, or is in his or her opinion, unsafe or unsanitary; or when the owner,
agent or tenant fails or refuses to comply with any lawful order issued by the
Building Inspector.
(Prior Code, § 152.09) (Ord. 726, passed 2-6-1961; Ord. 1087, passed 3-20-1972)
Penalty, see §
152.99
§ 152.10 NOTICE IN WRITING TO VACATE BUILDING.
   Every order of vacation shall be in writing and shall be served upon the
owner, agent or tenant, stating the reasons for the order and specifying the
time by which such vacation must be effected. When the Building Inspector shall
deem it necessary, a notice of vacation shall be posted in a conspicuous place
on the subject building. After the posting of any such notice or the service of
any such order of vacation, it shall be unlawful to occupy or permit the
occupancy of the subject premises, or any portion thereof, until the provisions
of this chapter and the requirements of all lawful orders issued by the
Building Inspector are complied with. When it shall appear to the Building
Inspector that the reasons for his or her order of vacation have ceased to
exist and that the subject building and the occupancy thereof are in compliance
with law and his or her orders, he or she shall in writing rescind such order
of vacation.
(Prior Code, § 152.10) (Ord. 726, passed 2-6-1961; Ord. 1087, passed 3-20-1972)
Penalty, see §
152.99
§ 152.11 REFERENCES IN CODES TO CITY AND OFFICIALS.
   All references to the state or the county, or to officials, departments or
agencies of the state or county, or to the Ohio Revised Code or the County
Building Code, in the Ohio Building Code for commercial construction and the
Residential Code of Ohio for residential construction shall be deemed to refer
to the city, its equivalent officials or departments, and the provisions of
this chapter, as applicable, and any other references of a particular nature in
the Ohio Building Code for commercial construction and the Residential Code of
Ohio for residential construction context thereof as the City Building Code.
(Prior Code, § 152.11) (Ord. 726, passed 2-6-1961; Ord. 1087, passed 3-20-1972)
§ 152.12 VARIANCES AND APPEALS FOR THE RESIDENTIAL BUILDING CODE.
   (A)   Purpose. The city has adopted the Hamilton County Building Code which
in turn has adopted the Residential Code of Ohio (O.A.C. Chapters 4101:8-1 to
4101:8-43, as amended and R.C. Chapter 3781, as amended). The purpose of this
section is to promote the public health, safety and welfare by creating a local
appeals process in order to hear and decide appeals of orders, decisions or
determinations made by the City Manager or Building Inspector relative to the
application of the Residential Code of Ohio (O.A.C. Chapters 4101:8-1 to 4101:
8-43, as amended and R.C. Chapter 3781, as amended).
   (B)   Appeals process.
      (1)   Any owner, builder, contractor or any person, firm or corporation
having a legal or equitable interest in a residential property (“eligible
appellant”) has the right to appeal any decision, order or determination made
by the City Manager or Building Inspector relative to the application of the
Residential Code of Ohio to said residential property. An eligible appellant
desiring to appeal any decision, order or determination made by the City
Manager or Building Inspector may do so by filing a written appeal to the Board
of Zoning Appeals.
      (2)   Requests for an appeals hearing shall be made in writing to the
Board of Zoning Appeals within 30 days of the date of the decision, order or
determination of the City Manager or Building Inspector. Each request shall be
accompanied with a processing fee of $75. The Board of Zoning Appeals shall
schedule a hearing within 60 days of receipt of the request and notify the
appellant of the hearing time, date and location by regular mail.
      (3)   All adjudication proceedings of the Board of Zoning Appeals shall
be conducted in accordance with R.C. §§ 119.09 and 119.13, as required by R.C.
§ 3781.031. The Board of Zoning Appeals shall have the authority to affirm,
modify or reserve the order, decision or ruling of the City Manager or the
Building Inspector and the authority to grant a variance from the terms of the
Residential Code of Ohio as set forth below. All decisions of the Board of
Zoning Appeals pertaining to appeals and variances related to the Residential
Code of Ohio shall be in writing.
         (a)   A decision, order or determination made by the City Manager or
Building Inspector may be reversed or modified, in full or in part, by the
Board of Zoning Appeals if it finds:
            1.   The decision, order or determination is contrary to the
Residential Code of Ohio or any other applicable law, rules, regulations and
ordinances;
            2.   The decision, order or determination is contrary to a
reasonable interpretation or application of the Residential Code of Ohio or any
other applicable law, rules, regulations and ordinances; or
            3.   That a variance from the provisions of the Residential Code of
Ohio, rules, regulations or ordinances, in a specific case, depending on the
facts established by the appellant, will not be contrary to the public interest
or safety of persons using said premises and where a literal enforcement of
such code provisions would result in unnecessary hardship.
         (b)   Such determination by the Board of Zoning Appeals shall be based
on the evidence presented at the hearing.
      (4)   For purposes of the appeals hearing, the Board of Zoning Appeals
may solicit the attendance of witnesses, production of records or documents and
may take the testimony of witnesses. All testimony shall be under oath, with a
record made and kept, along with such evidence as submitted.
      (5)   The Board of Zoning Appeals shall render its decision in writing
within 60 days after the conclusion of the appeals hearing. A certified copy of
the decision shall be mailed to the appellant by regular mail. Decisions of the
Board of Zoning Appeals, including all conditions, shall be enforced by the
City Manager or Building Inspector in keeping with the deadlines set by the
Board of Zoning Appeals.
      (6)   All decisions of the Board of Zoning Appeals are final. However, an
appeal from the decision of the Board of Zoning Appeals may be made to the
Court of Common Pleas in accordance with the applicable law, rule or
regulation. Such appeals must be made within 30 days of the date of the written
order of the Board of Zoning Appeals.
      (7)   Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in this section,
all appeals related to the Commercial Building Code (O.A.C. Chapters 4101:1-
1 et seq., as amended and R.C. Chapter 3781, as amended) shall be to the
Hamilton County Board of Building Appeals, if so contracted by the City Council
or the Ohio Board of Building Appeals, in accordance with the Ohio Revised
Code.
(Prior Code, § 152.12) (Ord. 91-22, passed 3-4-1991; Ord. 13-12, passed 3-11-
2013; Ord. 17-10, passed 9-25-2017)
§ 152.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person or entity who owns or controls any buildings, and violates
any regulation under, or provision or amendment of this chapter, or violates
any certificate or permit issued thereunder or fails to obey any lawful order
of the Building Inspector issued pursuant thereto shall upon conviction for
such violation or failure be fined not more than $150. Each day in which such
person or entity continues in such violation or failure shall be deemed a
separate offense.
   (B)   Any person or entity who assists in any violation shall upon
conviction of such assistance be fined not more than $150. Each day in which a
person or entity continues to assist in such violation shall be deemed a
separate offense.
(Prior Code, § 152.99) (Ord. 726, passed 2-6-1961; Ord. 1087, passed 3-20-1972;
Ord. 88-46, passed 11-7-1988; Ord. 04-21, passed 8-23-2004)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 153.001 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this Property Maintenance Code is to establish a minimum
standard necessary for the preservation of the public safety, health and
general welfare in all buildings or premises used or intended to be used for
dwelling purposes or other human occupation, as well as all other types of
unoccupied structures and to assign the responsibility of owners, operators and
occupants of such buildings, structures and accessory buildings.
(Prior Code, § 158.01) (Ord. 93-27, passed 6-21-1993)
§ 153.002 SCOPE.
   (A)   The provisions of this Property Maintenance Code are supplementary to
the sections of the Building Code. Conditions not in compliance with the
requirements of this code or the Building Code relating to the construction,
use and maintenance of buildings and structures are deemed to be safety and
sanitation hazards. All the provisions of this code and Building Code as
related above shall be retroactive and shall apply to all buildings and
structures; except whenever the applicable provisions of the Building Code
exceed this code or other legal requirements that were in effect at the time of
either the original construction, addition or reconstruction, as applicable,
then the least restrictive requirements of that particular construction,
addition or reconstruction shall apply.
   (B)   However, if the City Manager determines that the application of the
least restrictive requirement will result in an unsafe, unsanitary or other
hazardous condition, the City Manager shall apply a more restrictive
requirement up to, but not exceeding, the requirements of the then-current
Building Code.
   (C)   Appeals from the City Manager’s application of the more restrictive
requirement shall be heard by the Board of Zoning Appeals upon proper
application.
   (D)   The final determination shall be by a majority vote of the Board of
Zoning Appeals members.
   (E)   A public hearing shall not be required. If this code is determined to
be in conflict with the Building Code, the Building Code shall apply.
(Prior Code, § 158.02) (Ord. 93-27, passed 6-21-1993; Ord. 17-10, passed 9-25-
2017)
§ 153.003 DEFINITIONS.
   (A)   For the purpose of this chapter, certain terms and words are hereby
defined.
   (B)   Words used in the present tense shall include the future.
   (C)   The singular number shall include the plural and the plural, the
singular.
   (D)   The word “building” shall include the word “structure” and the word
“shall” is mandatory and not merely directory.
      DETERIORATION. The condition or appearance of the exterior of a building
or part thereof, characterized by holes, breaks, rot, crumbling or cracking,
peeling, rusting or other evidence of physical decay, neglect or lack of
maintenance.
      EXTERIOR OF THE PREMISES. Those portions of a building which are exposed
to public view and the open space of any premises outside of any building.
      GARBAGE. Animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling,
preparation, cooking and consumption of food.
      INFESTATION. The presence of insects, rodents, vermin or other pests on
the premises which constitute a health hazard.
      NUISANCE. That which is defined by the statutes of the state and declared
thereby to be a NUISANCE, and also includes conditions dangerous to human life
or detrimental to the health of persons on or near the premises where the
conditions exist, and where the conditions are perilous by active and negligent
operation thereof, and unsanitary conditions or anything offensive to the
senses or dangerous to health.
      OCCUPANT. Any person living and sleeping in a dwelling unit or having
actual possession of said dwelling unit or any person who leases or rents a
nonresidential building, structure or any portion thereof.
      OWNER. Any person, who, alone or jointly or severally with others, shall
have legal or equitable title to any premises, with or without the accompanying
actual possession thereof; or shall have charge, care or control as owner or
agent of the owner; or as executor, administrator, trustee, receiver or
guardian of an estate, or as a mortgagee in possession.
      PERSON. Any individual, corporation, association, partnership, trustee,
lessee, agent or assignee.
      PREMISES. A lot, plot or parcel of land, including the buildings or
structures thereon.
      REFUSE. All putrescible and nonputrescible solid wastes (except body
wastes) including but not limited to garbage, rubbish, ashes, dead animals and
industrial wastes; an accumulation of brush, broken glass, stumps and roots
that present a safety hazard, and includes garbage, trash and debris which
present an unsanitary and/or safety hazard.
      RUBBISH. Nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of both combustible and
noncombustible wastes, such as paper, wrappings, tin cans, yard clippings,
leaves, wood, glass, crockery, plastics and similar materials.
(Prior Code, § 158.03) (Ord. 93-27, passed 6-21-1993)
DANGEROUS AND UNSAFE BUILDINGS
§ 153.015 DEFECTS.
   All buildings or structures having defects as set forth herein shall be
deemed dangerous or unsafe:
   (A)   Those whose walls, floors, foundations or other members are so out of
plumb, level, original position or so deteriorated, or overloaded as to be
unlikely to perform their intended structural function, or are in such
condition or of such size as to cause stresses in any structural members likely
to result in failure or collapse;
   (B)   Those which are or have become so dilapidated, termite-infested,
decayed or unsafe, or which so substantially fail to provide the basic elements
of shelter or safety that, for that reason, they are unfit for human habitation
or dangerous to life or property;
   (C)   Those which are not provided with required and approved safe and
adequate means of egress;
   (D)   Those which in the opinion of the City Manager and a responsible
officer of the fire company constitute a serious fire hazard because of their
use, construction, unprotected exposure or lack of maintenance; and
   (E)   Those which are unsanitary or are a hazard to safety, health or
general welfare of any occupants or the public.
(Prior Code, § 158.05) (Ord. 93-27, passed 6-21-1993) Penalty, see §
153.999
ENVIRONMENTAL REQUIREMENTS
§ 153.030 GENERAL.
   The provisions of §§
153.030 through
153.034 shall govern the minimum conditions of buildings and structures. Every
building or structure and the premises on which it stands shall comply with the
conditions herein prescribed as they apply thereto.
(Prior Code, § 158.10) (Ord. 93-27, passed 6-21-1993)
§ 153.031 PROPERTY AREAS AND STRUCTURES.
   (A)   General. No person shall occupy as owner-occupant or otherwise permit
or let to another for occupancy any building which does not comply with the
following requirements. The City Manager shall cause inspections to be made of
such premises, as necessary, to secure compliance with these requirements.
   (B)   Sanitation. All interior and exterior property areas shall be
maintained in a clean and sanitary condition free from any accumulation of
rubbish and garbage that might constitute a health hazard.
   (C)   Grading and drainage. All premises shall be graded and maintained to
prevent the accumulation of stagnant water thereon or within any building or
structure located thereon.
   (D)   Noxious weeds. All property areas shall be kept free from species of
weeds or plant growth which are noxious or detrimental to the public health.
Noxious weeds include non-native plants and weeds, such as exotic plants that
are unnatural growths within the particular region of the city and southeast
Ohio.
(Prior Code, § 158.11) (Ord. 93-27, passed 6-21-1993; Ord. 21-04, passed 8-9-
2021) Penalty, see §
153.999
§ 153.032 FIRE PROTECTION FEATURES.
   Every building intended for human occupancy shall be protected with such
fire-protective features as may be required for the adequate protection of the
occupants thereof. The minimum requirements for such protection shall be as
required by the city.
(Prior Code, § 158.12) (Ord. 93-27, passed 6-21-1993) Penalty, see §
153.999
§ 153.033 GENERAL MAINTENANCE AND REPAIR.
   (A)   Every plumbing installation, gutter and downspout, supplied facility,
piece of equipment or utility shall be constructed or installed so that it will
function safely and shall be maintained in satisfactory working condition.
   (B)   No owner, operator or occupant shall cause any service, facility,
equipment or utility which is required under this Property Maintenance Code to
be removed, shut off from or discontinued for any occupied dwelling let or
occupied by him or her except for such temporary interruption as may be
necessary while actual repairs or alterations are in process or during
temporary emergencies.
   (C)   No object shall be placed and no restraining devices shall be
installed so as to interfere with the proper functioning of a required fire
door or other protective device or system.
   (D)   Each gas outlet, including a valve or cock outlet that is not being
used immediately, and each unused gas illuminating fixture shall be removed and
the line shall be securely closed gastight with a threaded plug or cap or, in
lieu thereof, a quick disconnect device that is listed by the American Gas
Association, Inc., Laboratories.
(Prior Code, § 158.13) (Ord. 93-27, passed 6-21-1993) Penalty, see §
153.999
§ 153.034 ANIMALS OR FOWL.
   It shall be unlawful to raise, breed or harbor any animals or fowl for
commercial purposes within the limits of the city, or for any other purpose
wherein they constitute a potential hazard or public nuisance.
(Prior Code, § 158.14) (Ord. 93-27, passed 6-21-1993) Penalty, see §
153.999
SPACE AND OCCUPANCY REQUIREMENTS
§ 153.045 BASIC FACILITIES.
   No person shall occupy as owner-occupant or let another for the purpose of
living, sleeping, cooking or eating therein any dwelling unit which does not
comply with the following requirements.
   (A)   Sanitary facilities. The following minimum sanitary facilities shall
be supplied and maintained.
      (1)   Toilet. Every dwelling unit shall contain within its walls a room,
separate from the habitable rooms, which affords privacy and which is equipped
with a flush toilet.
      (2)   Lavatory. Every dwelling unit shall contain a lavatory.
      (3)   Bathtub or shower. Every dwelling unit shall contain a room which
affords privacy to a person in the room, and which is equipped with a bathtub
or shower.
      (4)   Kitchen sink. Every dwelling unit shall contain a kitchen sink
apart from the lavatory required under division (A)(3) above.
   (B)   Water and sewer system. Every kitchen sink, lavatory basin, bathtub or
shower, and toilet required under the provisions of §§
153.045 through
153.047 shall be properly connected to either a public water and sewer system
or to an approved private water system. At no time shall it be permitted to
discharge waste into any waste disposal unit except as approved by the city.
All sinks, lavatories, bathtubs and showers shall be supplied with running
water.
   (C)   Operation of heating facilities and incinerators. Every heating or
water-heating facility shall be installed and shall operate in accordance with
the requirements of the air pollution control ordinances of the city and the
Madeira-Indian Hill Fire Department.
   (D)   Garbage and rubbish storage facilities.
      (1)   Every dwelling, multi-family dwelling and dwelling unit shall be
supplied with approved containers and covers for the storage of rubbish. The
owner, operator or agent in control of the dwelling or multi-family dwelling
shall be responsible for the removal of the rubbish.
      (2)   No dwelling or dwelling unit shall be deemed to comply with the
requirements of this code unless:
         (a)   Rubbish and garbage stored outdoors is stored in one or more
rubbish storage boxes or containers which are fly-tight, rodent-proof and
reasonably waterproof; and
         (b)   Rubbish and garbage stored in the basement or cellar or in an
enclosed structure such as a shed, is stored in nonflammable containers.
(Prior Code, § 158.20) (Ord. 93-27, passed 6-21-1993) Penalty, see §
153.999
§ 153.046 INSTALLATION AND MAINTENANCE.
   (A)   Gas systems and fixtures. All gas systems and fixtures shall be
installed and maintained in accordance with Duke Energy specifications.
   (B)   Electrical outlets and fixtures.
      (1)   Every electrical outlet and fixture shall be properly installed and
maintained according to the specifications of the National Electrical Code.
      (2)   No building shall be deemed to comply with the requirement of this
code unless:
         (a)   No temporary wiring is used, except extension cords which run
directly from portable electric fixtures to convenience outlets and which do
not lie underneath floor-covering materials or extend through doorways,
transoms or other similar apertures through structural elements; and
         (b)   Each electric circuit has wire and compatible fuses or circuit
breakers necessary to carry the electric load, and protect against accidental
overloading, as specified by the National Electrical Code.
   (C)   Correction of defective system. Where it is found, in the opinion of
the City Manager, that the electrical system in a building constitutes a hazard
to the occupants or the building itself by reason of inadequate service,
improper fusing, insufficient outlets, improper wiring or installation,
deterioration or damage of the above, or for similar reasons, he or she shall
order the defects to be corrected to eliminate the hazard.
   (D)   Heating facilities. Every building intended for occupancy shall have
heating facilities. The owner of the heating facilities shall be required to
see that they are properly installed, safely maintained, in good working
condition and capable of safely and adequately heating all habitable rooms,
bathrooms and toilet rooms located therein.
(Prior Code, § 158.21) (Ord. 93-27, passed 6-21-1993) Penalty, see §
153.999
§ 153.047 OCCUPANCY OF DWELLING UNITS BELOW GRADE.
   No cellar or basement space shall be used as a habitable room or dwelling
unit unless provided with adequate ventilation and natural or artificial light.
(Prior Code, § 158.22) (Ord. 93-27, passed 6-21-1993) Penalty, see §
153.999
RESPONSIBILITIES OF PERSONS
§ 153.060 GENERAL.
   (A)   Where in this Property Maintenance Code the obligation for observance
is not otherwise clearly designated, the respective responsibilities of owner,
operator and occupant shall be as specified in §§
153.061 and
153.062.
   (B)   A contract between the owner and operator, the operator and occupant,
or the owner and occupant, with regard to compliance with the provisions of
this code, shall not relieve any part of their direct responsibility under this
code.
   (C)   Every owner shall be responsible for complying with all the provision
of this code, other than those specifically excepted.
(Prior Code, § 158.25) (Ord. 93-27, passed 6-21-1993)
§ 153.061 RESPONSIBILITIES OF OWNERS OR OPERATORS.
   The responsibilities of owners or operators shall be as follows.
   (A)   Every owner or operator of a dwelling containing two or more
apartments or dwelling units shall be responsible for maintaining in a clean
and sanitary condition the shared or public areas of the dwelling and premises
thereof.
   (B)   No owner or operator shall occupy or let to another for occupancy any
vacant apartment or dwelling unit unless it is reasonably clean, sanitary and
fit for human occupancy.
   (C)   The owner or operator of a multiple dwelling containing two or more
household units shall supply approved rubbish and garbage disposal facilities
or approved garbage storage containers for all the apartments or household
units in the dwelling, shall be responsible for the clean and sanitary
maintenance of the common storage or disposal facilities, and shall be
responsible for the removal of the rubbish.
   (D)   Every owner or operator of every rooming house shall dispose of all
garbage and rubbish in a clean and sanitary manner by placing it in storage or
disposal facilities which are safe and sanitary.
   (E)   Every owner or occupant of any building shall be responsible for the
extermination of any insects, rodents or other pests as follows:
      (1)   Whenever infestation exists in any apartment or household unit in
any dwelling or in the shared or public areas of any dwelling, and it is not
practicable to establish occupant responsibility; or
      (2)   Whenever infestation is caused by failure of the owner or operator
to maintain a building in a rodent-proof or substantially insect-proof
condition.
(Prior Code, § 158.26) (Ord. 93-27, passed 6-21-1993) Penalty, see §
153.999
§ 153.062 RESPONSIBILITIES OF OCCUPANTS.
   (A)   The responsibilities of occupants shall be as follows.
      (1)   Every occupant of a building shall maintain in a clean and sanitary
condition all parts of the premises which he or she occupies, uses and
controls; and shall be responsible for his or her own misuse of areas or
facilities available in common.
      (2)   Every occupant of a building occupied by more than one apartment,
household unit or business shall provide himself or herself with approved
storage containers or disposal facilities, and shall dispose of all rubbish,
ashes, garbage and other wastes in a clean and sanitary manner by placing them
in an approved storage or disposal facility, in accordance with regulations of
the Board of Health.
      (3)   Every occupant of a dwelling or dwelling unit shall be responsible
for hanging all screens and double or storm doors and windows whenever the same
are required under the provisions of this code, except where the owner has
agreed to supply those services.
      (4)   Occupants of a single-family dwelling shall be responsible for the
extermination of any insects, rodents or other pests therein or on the
premises.
      (5)   Occupants of any building shall be responsible for the
extermination of any insects, rodents or other pests therein or on the premises
whenever the occupants are at fault.
      (6)   Occupants of a building shall keep all facilities, including
plumbing fixtures and cooking equipment, in a clean and sanitary condition, and
shall be responsible for the exercise of reasonable care and the proper use and
operation thereof.
      (7)   No occupant shall deposit material in any plumbing or electrical
fixture which will result in stoppage of or damage to the fixture. It shall be
the responsibility of the occupant to correct any stoppages determined to be
due to improper use or neglect.
      (8)   The occupant, when moving to another location, shall leave the
vacated premises in a reasonably clean and sanitary condition.
   (B)   Any occupant of a building or premises who creates a condition which
constitutes a violation of the standards established by this code shall be
punishable for a violation in accordance with the penalty provisions of §
153.999.
(Prior Code, § 158.27) (Ord. 93-27, passed 6-21-1993) Penalty, see §
153.999
§ 153.063 MAINTENANCE OF PROPERTY BEING DEVELOPED OR EXCAVATED DURING PERIODS
OF INACTIVITY.
   (A)   Background, purpose and intent.
      (1)   The purpose and intent of this section is to establish minimum
standards for the maintenance of property being developed or excavated and
construction sites during periods of inactivity. The requirements contained in
this section are designed to minimize the possibility of property damage and
personal injury and simultaneously minimize the adverse visual effects of
halted or abandoned construction projects through cooperative efforts between
the property owners, developer, surrounding property owners, the county and the
city. The City Council believes that the requirements of this section
appropriately balance the rights provided to developers and property owners
with the rights of the city and surrounding property owners.
      (2)   The city recognizes that the Board of County Commissioners has
adopted Rules and Regulations for the Construction, Operation, Maintenance and
use of the Storm Drainage System of Hamilton County, Ohio (“County Rules and
Regulations”). The city intends to supplement such regulations, but in cases of
inconsistency or preemption, defer to the County Rules and Regulations. The
city further intends to supplement rather than override any other provisions of
this Chapter 153 and the Building Code as they apply to the property that is
subject to this section.
      (3)   Additionally, the purposes of this section are to:
         (a)   Prevent incomplete, abandoned or halted construction from
increasing flood or drainage hazards to others;
         (b)   Promote the public health, safety and general welfare of its
citizens from the hazards of flooding and diminished property values;
         (c)   Lessen the burden on the taxpayer for flood control, repairs to
public facilities and utilities, and flood rescue and relief operations;
         (d)   Maintain property values and a stable tax base by minimizing the
potential for creating blight areas; and
         (e)   Preserve the natural characteristics and functions of
watercourses and floodplains in order to moderate flood and stormwater impacts,
improve water quality, reduce soil erosion, protect aquatic and riparian
habitat, preserve recreational opportunities, provide aesthetic benefits and
enhance community and economic development.
   (B)   Definitions. For the purpose of this section, the following
definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning.
      COMMENCED. The beginning of a designated activity to a degree that it
visually alters the property.
      DESIGNATED ACTIVITY. The commencement of any construction or demolition
activity, including but not limited to the removal of large trees, grading or
excavation.
      PERIOD OF INACTIVITY. The voluntary or involuntary cessation of a
significant part of the designated activity for 45 consecutive days.
Furthermore, insignificant activity, such as simply moving equipment, materials
or dirt without meaningful re-commencement of designated activities as
determined by the City Manager shall not toll the running of the 45-day period.
   (C)   Requirements.
      (1)   Any person who owns a vacant, developed or undeveloped property on
which one or more or a combination of designated activity are commenced and are
subsequently subject to a period of inactivity, shall undertake, as applicable,
in the discretion of the City Manager, one or more of the following:
         (a)   Prepare the ground, apply lime and fertilizer, sow seed, mulch,
apply nitrogen, water, maintain and undertake all reasonable steps taken in the
industry to provide a viable grass coverage that stabilizes the ground surface
against erosion;
         (b)   Keep property free of brush and weeds, dead and dying trees and
other growth which are inimical to the preservation of public health, safety or
general welfare of the public or which may constitute a fire hazard;
         (c)   Prune hedges, trees and other foliage along property lines so
that they do not impinge on neighboring properties, rights-of-way, or overhang
or obstruct sidewalks;
         (d)   Immediately remove all construction equipment, vehicles or
construction materials from the property; and/or
         (e)   Fill holes, depressions and voids created or exposed by clearing
or excavation operations with soil.
      (2)   Upon notice and verification by the City Manager that the
designated activity is subject to a period of inactivity, the City Manager
shall follow the enforcement procedures in §§
153.075 through
153.081 of the City Property Maintenance Code.
   (D)   Preemption. In the event of a conflict between the County Rules and
Regulations and this section, the provisions of the County Rules and
Regulations shall prevail. In the event of a conflict between the City Building
Code or city zoning code and this section, the applicable provisions of the
Building Code or the zoning code shall prevail.
   (E)   Reservation of rights. The city expressly reserves all rights and
remedies afforded to it under other provisions of the codified ordinances of
the city and other state and federal law.
   (F)   Severability. If any section, division, clause or phrase of this
section is for any reason held to be unconstitutional or invalid, such decision
shall not affect the remaining portions of this section.
(Prior Code, § 158.28) (Ord. 08-11, passed 3-24-2008) Penalty, see §
153.999
ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT
§ 153.075 ENFORCEMENT OFFICER.
   It shall be the duty and responsibility of the City Manager or his or her
approved representative to enforce the provisions of this Property Maintenance
Code as herein provided.
(Prior Code, § 158.30) (Ord. 93-27, passed 6-21-1993)
§ 153.076 COORDINATION OF ENFORCEMENT.
   Whenever, in the opinion of the City Manager, it is necessary or desirable
to have inspections of any condition by more than one department, he or she
shall arrange for this to be done in such a manner that the owners or occupants
of buildings shall not be subjected to visits by numerous inspectors nor to
conflicting order.
(Prior Code, § 158.31) (Ord. 93-27, passed 6-21-1993)
§ 153.077 INSPECTIONS.
   Where there exists a reasonable cause to suspect that a condition exists
adverse to the safety, health and welfare of the people, the City Manager shall
make or cause to be made inspections by his or her authorized representative,
the Board of Health or the Fire Inspector to determine the conditions of
dwellings, multi-family dwellings, dwelling units, rooming houses, rooming
units and premises in order to safeguard the safety, health and welfare of the
public under the provisions of this code. All reports of inspections shall be
in writing and signed by the person making same or responsible for making same.
City Manager is hereby authorized to seek and obtain from a court of law an
administrative search warrant whenever it is deemed necessary to gain entrance
onto property or into a building for inspection of premises where there is
reasonable cause to believe a violation may exist.
(Prior Code, § 158.32) (Ord. 93-27, passed 6-21-1993)
§ 153.078 UNSAFE, DANGEROUS AND UNSANITARY BUILDINGS.
   Whenever, upon inspection it shall appear that an unsafe, dangerous or
unsanitary condition exists in connection with any building or premises subject
to the provisions of this code or that any condition exists constituting a
violation of any provision of this code or any law relating to the same subject
matter, the City Manager shall give notice of the condition or violation to the
owner or agent in charge of the building, and shall order the same to be made
safe, secure or sanitary and to be placed in substantial compliance with the
provisions of this code, or to be taken down and removed. The City Manager or a
designated representative, in addition to any other citations, notices,
penalties or remedies provided by law or ordinance, is authorized to proceed in
a manner consistent with and pursuant to R.C. §§ 715.26 and 715.261 to maintain
the public health, safety and welfare and to recover costs as appropriate.
(Prior Code, § 158.33) (Ord. 93-27, passed 6-21-1993) Penalty, see §
153.999
§ 153.079 SERVICE OF NOTICE.
   Unless otherwise specifically provided for, the service of any notice
required by the provisions of this code to be served on the owner, agent,
contractor, responsible person or other person responsible for the work or
violation in connection with any violation of the code or the construction,
reconstruction, repair, removal, vacation or wrecking of any building, object
or device on such property may be made in any of the following ways:
   (A)   By personal delivery to the party involved;
   (B)   By certified mail addressed to the party involved at his or her
residence or place of business; or
   (C)   Where the residence and place of business of the party is unknown and
cannot be ascertained with reasonable diligence or where, for any other reason,
personal service or service by mail cannot be made, the notice shall be posted
in a conspicuous place on the premises.
(Prior Code, § 158.34) (Ord. 93-27, passed 6-21-1993; Ord. 19-06, passed 11-25-
2019; Ord. 21-04, passed 8-9-2021)
§ 153.080 WRITTEN ORDER OF VACATION.
   (A)   Every order of vacation shall be in writing, and shall be served upon
the owner, agent or tenant stating the reasons for the order of vacation and
directing that the building, if it is occupied, be vacated by a specific time.
The City Manager shall place a notice of vacation in a conspicuous place on the
building. After the posting of the notice or order of vacation, it shall be
unlawful to occupy or permit the occupancy of the premises or any portion
thereof until the provisions of law and the orders issued by the City Manager
are complied with.
   (B)   Failure to comply with any lawful order of the City Manager within the
time specified in the order of notice shall constitute a misdemeanor punishable
as provided for in §
153.999.
(Prior Code, § 158.35) (Ord. 93-27, passed 6-21-1993) Penalty, see §
153.999
§ 153.081 FAILURE TO COMPLY WITH CODE REGULATIONS.
   If, after service of any lawful order from the City Manager, the owner,
agent, contractor or other person responsible for the work or violation refuses
to comply with the order or does not comply within the period stated in the
order of notice, such failure to comply shall constitute a misdemeanor
punishable as provided for in §
153.999 of this code.
(Prior Code, § 158.36) (Ord. 93-27, passed 6-21-1993) Penalty, see §

SHRUBBERY; STANDING WATER
§ 153.095 DEFINITIONS; KEEPING DOWN WEEDS.
   (A)   For the purpose of this subchapter and any penalty provisions in
connection herewith, the following definitions shall apply unless the context
clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
      FARM CROP. Shall include any field crops, tobacco, fruits and vegetables.
      FRONT YARD. Any section of land between a dwelling or other building and
the roadway upon which such dwelling or building is situated.
      NATIVE PLANTS. Plants that have evolved over thousands of years within
the particular region of the City of Madeira and southeast Ohio, naturally
adapting to the geography, hydrology and climate of that region. The approved
native plant list can be found in §
153.099.
      NOXIOUS. Harmful or offensive.
      RANK. Excessive in growth; exceeding eight inches in height.
      RESPONSIBLE PERSON. Any person owning or having charge of land within the
city, including, but not limited to, the owner, lessee, agent or tenant having
charge of the land involved. If the land involved is owned or controlled by a
limited liability company, limited liability partnership or corporation, then
the RESPONSIBLE PERSON may also include the controlling members, partners or
shareholders of such entity.
      TURF GRASS. Grass commonly used in regularly-cut lawns or play areas,
whether dead or alive, except as provided in §
153.097.
   (B)   Any person owning or having charge of land within the city shall keep
such land free and clear from all rank or noxious weeds, grasses and
vegetation, except trees, shrubs, garden variety flowers, native plants and
farm crops, by cutting or other effective legal means of control.
   (C)   Any person owning or having charge of land within the city shall keep
such land free from all weeds, grasses and vegetation, except trees, shrubs,
garden variety flowers, native plants and farm crops, by cutting or other
effective legal means of control whenever such weeds, grasses or vegetation are
pollinating or are about to spread or mature seeds, and at any other time as is
necessary to keep the growth of such weeds under eight inches in height.
   (D)   If the owner or other responsible person fails to cut the weeds,
grasses and vegetation before they exceed eight inches in height, then such
owner or responsible person shall have the duty and obligation to remove all or
substantially all clippings and waste resulting from the cutting of such weeds,
grasses and vegetation.
   (E)   Any person owning or having charge of land within the city shall not
plant, maintain or cultivate farm crops in the front yard of such property.
   (F)   Shrubbery or other vegetation shall not be permitted to grow in a
manner that is a danger to the occupants of a dwelling or other building or to
the public health, safety and welfare, or in a manner that creates, extends or
intensifies blighting or deteriorating conditions. Such manner shall include
but is not limited to:
      (1)   Shrubbery or vegetation that is overgrown to the point that it
impedes the delivery of governmental services, such as police, fire and rescue
services;
      (2)   Shrubbery or vegetation that is overgrown to the point that it
infringes on any neighboring property owner’s right of quiet enjoyment of his
or her property; or
      (3)   Shrubbery or vegetation that has grown in a manner such that it has
infiltrated the siding or other building materials of a dwelling.
(Prior Code, § 158.40) (Ord. 08-20, passed 4-28-2008; Ord. 19-06, passed 11-25-
2019; Ord. 21-04, passed 8-9-2021) Penalty, see §
153.999
§ 153.096 DEFINITIONS; REMOVING STANDING WATER.
   (A)   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
      HUMAN-MADE AREA. Any area of land which was altered or depressed by any
means other than natural means.
      RESPONSIBLE PERSON. Any person owning or having charge of land within the
city, including, but not limited to, the owner, lessee, agent or tenant having
charge of the land involved.
      STANDING WATER. Water that is not flowing; stagnant.
   (B)   (1)   Any person owning or having charge of land within the city shall
keep such land free and clear from all excessive standing water or any human-
made areas of standing water by any effective legal means.
      (2)   If the owner or other responsible person fails to comply with this
section, then the owner or other responsible person shall have the duty and
obligation to remove all such standing water. No owner or other responsible
person is permitted to divert such standing water onto the property of another.
   (C)   Water shall not be permitted to stand in a manner that is dangerous to
the occupants of a dwelling or other building or to the public health, safety
and welfare, or in a manner that creates, extends or intensifies blighting or
deterioration conditions. Such manner shall include, but is not limited to:
      (1)   Water that has collected to the point that it impedes the delivery
of governmental services, such as police, fire and rescue services;
      (2)   Water that has collected to the point that it infringes on any
neighboring property owner’s right of quiet enjoyment of his or her property;
      (3)   Water that has collected in such a manner that it has infiltrated
the building materials of a dwelling;
      (4)   Water that has collected that attracts, or creates a risk of
attracting, insects, including, but not limited to, mosquitoes; or
      (5)   Water that has collected that creates an environment conducive to
the development of health risks, including, but not limited to, mold, mildew
and bacteria.
(Prior Code, § 158.41) (Ord. 08-20, passed 4-28-2008) Penalty, see §
153.999
§ 153.097 DEFINITIONS; MANAGED NATURAL LANDSCAPING.
   (A)   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
      MANAGED NATURAL LANDSCAPING AREA. Designed and cultivated plant
communities that are self-sustaining with minimal resort to artificial methods
of plant care and that serve at least one of the following purposes:
         (a)   The attraction and aid of wildlife;
         (b)   The offset and control of a potential or existing soil loss
program;
         (c)   The enrichment or stabilization of soil fertility;
         (d)   Pest control;
         (e)   Governmental programs, including, without limitation, stormwater
control;
         (f)   Educational studies; and
         (g)   Food production.
   (B)   The height restrictions provided in §
153.095 shall not apply to natural plants on privately owned, occupied
residential property and properties contiguous to the privately owned, occupied
residential property provided that such contiguous properties are owned by the
same individual, when such natural plants are part of a managed natural
landscape area.
   (C)   Managed natural landscaped areas shall be set back a minimum of three
feet from all property lines, roads, alleys and/or driveways unless the
property is abutted by a fence or similar barrier separating it from adjoining
residential properties, then the natural landscaping may be planted up to the
property line (inside the sidewalk). With the exception of trees, all
vegetation in the right-of-way strip between the sidewalk and street must be
kept at a height of less than ten inches.
   (D)   Managed natural landscaped areas shall not be permitted to overhang or
encroach onto any public or private properties, or public sidewalks, streets or
alleys adjacent to the lot, tract or parcel on which they are planted.
   (E)   Managed natural landscaped areas shall be permitted to be up to 25% of
the area of the front yard and up to 50% of the area of the rear yard.
   (F)   For purposes of this section, the front and rear yard of a property
shall be determined by the halfway point of the subject lot; it will not follow
the zoning code definition of front and rear yard.

(Prior Code, § 158.42) (Ord. 21-04, passed 8-9-2021; Ord. 22-08, passed 8-22-
2022)
§ 153.098 DEFINITIONS; ABANDONED PROPERTY; ABATEMENT.
   (A)   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
      ABANDONED PROPERTY. Property that is not being maintained consistent with
the requirements of this
Chapter 153 and that the property owner or person in control has failed to
bring into compliance with this
Chapter 153 within seven days of receiving a notice of violation and civil
fine.
      ABATEMENT. The removal of any conditions in accordance with this section
that are the subject of a notice of violation.
   (B)   Due to the recurring nature of the violations in §
153.095, if the person, responsible person or entity that owns or controls any
property subject to a notice violation and fine fails to bring the subject
property into compliance with §
153.095 within five days after receiving a notice violation and fine, the
subject property shall be identified as an abandoned property as defined
herein.
   (C)   If subsequent violations occur at an abandoned property:
      (1)   The City Manager or the City Manager’s designee shall place the
property on a list of abandoned properties that will be routinely inspected,
pursuant to guidelines established by the City Manager or City Manager’s
designee;
      (2)   If the property is subsequently found to be in violation of §
153.095, the City Manager or the City Manager’s designee immediately shall
cause any weeds and/or turf grasses that exceed the height restrictions
specified in §
153.095 to be cut, as set forth in §
153.095; and
      (3)   Inspection and abatement of the abandoned property shall continue
as long as the condition persists, with a §
92.47 notice violation sent each time, and may continue into the following
calendar years.
   (D)   The City Manager or the City Manager’s designee shall report all
expenses involved in the cutting of such weeds and turf grass, including the
cost of service of notice, any administrative costs and inspection costs, to
Council.
   (E)   The obligation of any mortgagee or person in control as defined in
Chapter 152 to comply with all of the obligations of the applicable Building
Code regulations is not modified by this section.
(Prior Code, § 158.43) (Ord. 21-04, passed 8-9-2021)

§ 153.999 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person, responsible person, or entity that owns or controls any
property area or structure that is served with a notice after violating or
assisting in the violation of any regulation, provision or amendment of this
Property Maintenance Code, or fails to obey any lawful order of the City
Manager issued in pursuance thereof, shall be in violation of the Property
Maintenance Code and fined not more than $150.
   (B)   Any person, responsible person, or entity who fails to comply with the
height restrictions specified in §
153.095 shall be in violation of the Property Maintenance Code upon receipt of
notice under §
153.079.
      (1)   Any person, responsible person or entity that owns or controls any
property area or structure served with a notice under §
153.095 shall have five days from service of the notice to remediate the
violation(s) identified and must maintain compliance with this Property
Maintenance Code regarding the noticed violation(s) on the subject property.
      (2)   Any person, responsible person or entity that owns or controls any
property area or structure that fails to remediate the violation(s) identified
by the notice within five days of being served with the notice shall be fined
not less than $150 per offense.
         (a)   Once a property becomes an abandoned property as defined in §
153.098, the owner or person in control of that property shall keep it free
from weeds and turf grasses over eight inches in height by cutting and then
removing said cut weeds and turf grasses from such lot or lands immediately.
         (b)   If subsequent violations occur at an abandoned property, in
addition to imposition of civil fines, the city will abate all subsequent
violations pursuant to §
153.098.
   (C)   Any civil fines collected under this chapter shall be deposited into
the Private Lot Abatement Fund to support §
153.098 abatement activities and enforcement of this
Chapter 153.
(Prior Code, § 158.99) (Ord. 93-27, passed 6-21-1993; Ord. 04-21, passed 8-23-
2004; Ord. 19-06, passed 11-25-2019; Ord. 21-04, passed 8-9-2021)
